editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A new wonder, a woman never vexed.
A pleasant conceited comedy: sundry times acted: never before printed.
Written by William Rowley, one of his majesty's servants.
London, imprinted by G. P. for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the crane in saint Paul's churchyard. 1632.

div.head: A new wonder, a woman never vexed.
Actus primus.
div.stage: Enter old Foster, alderman bruyne and two Factors 〈◊〉 chard, and george

sp.speaker: Old foster.
sp.l: This air has a sweet a breath master Bruyno

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Your partner sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, and in good I hope, this halcyon gale
sp.p: Plays the lewd wanton with our dancing sails,
sp.l: And makes 'em big with vaporous envy.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: 'Tis no more yet, but then our fraught is full
When she returns laden with merchandise
And safe delivered with our customage.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Such a delivery heaven send us,
But time must ripen it? are our accounts made even?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: To the quantity of a penny, if his agree with mines
What's yours Richard?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Five hundred sixty pounds;
read the gross sum of your broad clothes.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: 68. pieces at b, ss, and l; 57. at l, ss, and o.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Just; lead, xix ton.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: As evenly we will lay our bosoms as our bottoms
With love as merchandise, and may they both increase
To infinites.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Especially at home; that golden traffic love
Is scantier far than gold; and one mine of that
More worth than twenty argosies
Of the world's richest treasure.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Here you shall dig, and find your lading.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Here's your exchange; and as in love
So we'll participate in merchandise.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: The merchant's casualty:
We always venture on uncertain odds,
Although we bear hopes emblem the anchor with us.
The wind brought it, let the wind blow't away again;
Should not the sea sometimes be partner with us
Our wealth would swallow us.

sp.speaker: ●r
sp.l: A good resolve: but now I must be bold
To touch you with somewhat that concerns you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I could prevent you; is't not my unthrifty brother?
Nay, leave out the adjective (Unthrifty,)
Your brother sir, 'tis he that I would speak of.
He cannot be named without unthrifty sir,
It's his proper epithet, would you conceit
●ut what my love has done for him
So oft, so chargeable, and so expensive,
You would not urge another addition.
Nay sir, you must not stay acquantity
〈…〉 the name of brother
Which is inseparable, he's now in Ludgate sir,
And part of your treasure lies buried with him.

sp.speaker: O. ●●st
sp.l: Ay, by vulgar blemish; but not by any good account;
There let him howl, as the best stay he hath;
For nothing but a prison can contain him
So boundless is his riot; twice have I raised
his decayed fortunes to a fair estate
But with as fruitless charity, as if I had thrown
My safe landed substance back into the sea,
Or dress in pity some corrupted jade,
And he should kick me for my courtesy.
I am sure you cannot but hear, what quick.
Sands he finds out, as dice, cards, pigeon-holes,
And which is more, should I not restrain it,
He'd make my state his prodigality.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: All this may be sir, yet examples daily show
To our eyes, that prodigals return at last
And the loudest roarer, (As our city phrase is)
Will speak calm and smooth; you must help with hope sir,
Had I such a brother, I should think that heaven had
Made him as an instrument for my best charity
To work upon; this is a maxim sure, some
Are made poor, that rich men by giving may
Increase their store. Nor think sir, that I do
Tax your labours and mean myself for to stand
Idly by, for I have vowed if heaven but bless
This voyage now abroad, to leave some
Memorable relic after me, that shall
Preserve my name alive till doomsday.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I sir, that work is good, and therein could I
Join with your good intents, but to relieve
A waste-good, a spendthrift. —

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: O no more, no more good sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sirrah, when saw you my son Robert ▪

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This morning sir, he said he would go visit his uncle

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I pay for their meetings I'm sure; that boy
Makes prize of all his fingers light on
To relieve his unthrifty uncle.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Does he rob, introth I commend him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: 'Tis partly your fault, sirrah you see't, and suffer it,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Sir, mine's a servant's duty, his a son's,
Nor know I better how to express my love
Unto yourself, than by loving your son.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: By concealing of his pilferings.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I dare not call them so; he is my second master,
And methinks 'tis far above my limits
Either to check, or to complain of him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Gramercy Du●, then mak'st a good construction,
And your son Robert a natural nephew's part.
To relieve his poor uncle.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: ●in neither well; sir, for note but the
Condition of my estate; I'm lately married
To a wealthy widow from whom my substance
Chiefely does arise, she has observed this in her
Son in law often complains and grudges at it,
And what foul broils such civil discords bring,
Few married men are ignorant of:
Nay will you see a present proof of it.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Shall I not live to breathe a quiet hour?
I would I were a beggar with content
Rather than thus be thwarted for mine own.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why what's the matter woman?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: I'll touse 'em up, though you regard not of my just complaints
sp.l: Neither in love to me, nor preserving me from others
Injuries, both which you're tied to, by all the rightful
Laws heavenly or humane, but I'll complain
Sir, where I will be heard.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Nay, thou'lt be heard too far.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Nay sir, I will be heard; some awkward star
Threw out his unhappy ●eat my conception
And 'twill never quench while I have heat in me:
Would I were cold, there would be bonfires made
So warm defame, my death would be a jubilee to some.

sp.speaker: O ▪ Fost.
sp.p: Why sir, how should I minister remedy and know not the cause.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Mother a pearl, woman, show your husband the cause,

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: Had he been a husband sir, I had had no cause to complain, I threw down at his feet
sp.l: The subjection of his whole estate:
He did not marry me for love's sake nor for pity,
But love to that I had, he now neglects the love
He had before; a prodigal is suffered to lay waste
Those worldly blessings, which I long enclosed,
Intending for good uses.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: That's my son.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: Ay, thou knowest it well enough, he's the conduit pipe that throws it forth into the common shore.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And the other's my brother.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: You may well shame, as I do grieve the kindred,
But I'd make the one a stranger, the other a servant,
No son, nor brother; for they deserve neither
Of those offices.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why did I ever cherish him, have not I threatened
Him with disinheritance for this disorder?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Why do you not perform it?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: The other's in Ludgate.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: No; he's in my house, approving to my face
The charitable office of his kind nephew,
Who with his pilfering purloined from me,
Has set him at liberty; if this may be suffered
I'll have no eyes to see.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Prithee content thyself; I'll see a present
Remedy; sirrah, go call 'em in; this worthy
Gentleman shall know the cause, and censure
For us both with equity.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Nay good sir, let not me be so employed,
For I shall favour one for pity, the other for your love's sake,

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Now sir, are all my words with you
So light esteemed that they can
Take no hold upon your duty?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Misconstrue not, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Nay, he'll approve his good deeds I warrant you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And you sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I had thought you had been in Ludgate sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Why, you see where I am sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost
sp.l: Why, where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: In debt sir, in debt.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Indeed that's a place you can hardly be removed
From, but this is not a place fit for one in
Debt, how came you out of prison sirrah?
As I went into prison sirrah, by the keepers.

sp.speaker: O. Fost
sp.l: This was your work to let this bandog lose.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir it was my duty to let my uncle lose.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Your duty did belong to me, and I did not command

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You cannot make a separation sir, betwixt
The duty that belongs to me, and love unto
My uncle, as well you may bid me love my
Maker, and neglect the creature, which he
Hath bid me love; if man to man join not
A love on earth, they love not heaven, nor
Him that dwells above it, such is my duty
A strong correlative unto
My uncle why, he's half yourself.
Believe me sir, he has answered you well.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: He has not worthy sir, but to make void
That false construction; here I disclaim
The title of a brother; and by that disclaim
Hast thou lost thy child's part; be thou engaged
For any debts of his, in prison rot with him;
My goods shall not purchase such
Fruitless recompense.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Then thou'rt a scurvy father, and a filthy brother.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, ay, sir, your tongue cannot defame his reputation

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: But yours can, for all the city reports what
An abominable scold he has got to his wife.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: If ere I know thou keepest him company,
I'll take my blessing from thee whilst I live,
And that which after me should bless thy estate.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: And I'll proclaim thy baseness to the world;
ballads I'll make, and make 'em tavern music
To sing thy churlish cruelty.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Tut, tut, these are babbles.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Each festival day I'll come unto thy house,
And I will piss upon thy threshold.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: You must be out of prison first sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: If e'er I live to see thee sheriff of London,
I'll gild thy painted posts cum privilegio,
And kick thy sergeants.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, good uncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why, I'll beg for thee, boy;
I'll break this leg, and bind it up again,
To pull out pity from a stony breast,
Rather than thou shalt want.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, do; let him fear up his arm, and scarf it up
With two yards of rope; counterfeit two villains;
Beg under a hedge and share your bounty: but come
Not near my house, not thou in's company, if thoul't obey,
There's punishment, for thee; for thee there's worse;
The loss of all that's mine, with my dear curse.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Churl, dog, you churlish rascally miser.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, good uncle, throw not foul language;
This is but heat sir, and I doubt not but
To cool this rage with my obedience:
But uncle, you must not then heap on such fuel.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Coz, I grieve for thee, that thou hast undergone
Thy father's curse, for love unto thy uncle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Tut, that bond shall ne'er be cancelled, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I pity that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let pity then from me turn to yourself:
Bethink yourself sir, of some course
That might befit your estate, and let me guide it.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha, a course? 'sfoot I hate: coz, canst lend me
40. shillings? Could I but repair this old decayed tenement
Of mine with some new plaster; for alas, what
Can a man do in such a case as this?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.l: Ay, but your course, uncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Tush, leave that to me, because thou shalt wonder
At it: if you should see me in a scarlet gown
Within the compass of a gold chain, than I
Hope you'll say, that I do keep myself in
Good compass: then sir, if the cap of maintenance
Do march before me, and not a cap be suffered
To be worn in my presence, pray do not upbraid
Me with my former poverty: I cannot tell, state
And wealth may make a man forget himself;
But I beseech you do not; there are things in my
Head that you dream not of; dare you try me, coz?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, forty shillings, uncle, shall not keep back your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why, gramercy coz; now if the dice do run right,
This 40. shillings may set me up again: to lay't on my back,
And so to pawn it, there's ne'er a damned broker
In the world will give me half the worth on't:
No, whilst 'tis in ready cash, that's the surest
Way; 7. is better than 11. a pox take the bones
And they will not favour a man sometimes.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Look you uncle, there's 40. shillings for you.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: As many good angels guard thee, as thou hast given
Me bad ones to seduce me, for these deputy devil's
Dam worse than the old ones. Now coz, pray listen,
Listen after my transformation; I will henceforth
Turn an apostate to prodigality; I will eat
Cheese and onions and buy lordships, and will
Not you think this strange?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am glad you're merry, uncle; but this is fixed
Betwixt an uncle and a nephew's love,
Though my estate be poor, revenues scant,
Whilst I have any left, you shall not want.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why gramercy, by this hand I'll make
Thee an alderman before I die, do but
Follow my steps.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Sirrah, will the churchman come I sent you for?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes, mistress, he will come: but pray resolve
Me one thing for my long service; what
Business have you with the churchman?
Is it to make your will, or to get you a new
Husband?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Suppose to make my will, how then?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Then I would desire you to remember me, mistress,
I have served you long, and that's the best
Service to a woman: make a good will if you
Mean to die, that it may not be said, though
Most women be long lived, yet they all die
With an ill-will.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: So sir, suppose it be for marriage.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Why then remember yourself mistress;
Take heed how you give away the head;
It stands yet upon the shoulders of
Your widowhood; the loving embracing ivy
Has yet the upper place in the house;
If you give it to the holly, take heed,
There's pricks in holly; or if you fear not
The pricks, take heed of the wands, you
Cannot have the pricks without the wands;
You give away the sword, and must defend
Yourself with the scabbard; these are pretty
Instructions of a friend; I would be loath to
See you cast down, and not well taken up.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Well sir, well, let not all this trouble you;
See, he's come; will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I will first give him a caveat, to use you
As kindly as he can. If you find my mistress
Have a mind to this coupling at barleybreak,
Let her not be the last couple to be left in hell.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I would I knew your meaning, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: If she have a mind to a fresh husband, or
so, use her as well as you can; let her enter
Into as easy bands as may be.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sir, this is none of my traffic; I sell no husbands.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Then you do wrong, sir, for you take money for 'em:
What woman can have a husband, but you must
Have custom for him? and often the ware proves
Naught too not worth the impost.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Your man's pregnant, and merry, mistress.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: He's saucy sir. Sirrah, you'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay, at the second hand you'll have a fee too;
You sell in the church, and they bring 'em again
To your churchyard, you must have tollage:
Methinks if a man die whether you will or no,
He should be buried whether you would or no.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nay now you wade too far, sir.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You'll be gone, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Mistress make him your friend, for he knows what rate
Good husbands are at; if there hath been a dearth
Of women of late, you may chance pick
Out a good prize; but take heed of a clerk.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Will you yet sir, after your needless trouble,
Be gone, and bid the maids dress dinner.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Mistress, 'tis fasting day today, there's nothing but fish.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Let there be store of that; let bounty furnish the
Table, and charity shall be the voider.
What fish is there, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Marry there is salmon, pike, and fresh cod,
Soles, maids, and plaice.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Bid 'em haste to dress 'em then.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay mistress, I'll help 'em too; the maids shall first
Dress the pike, and the cod, and then I'll dress
The maids in the place you wot on.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You sent for me, gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Sir, I did, and to this end:
I have some scruples in my conscience;
Some doubtful problems which I cannot answer
Nor reconcile; I'd have you make them plain.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: This is my duty; pray speak your mind.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: And as I speak, I must remember heaven
That gave those blessings which I must relate:
Sir, you now behold a wondrous woman;
You only wonder at the epithet;
I can approve it good; guess at mine age.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: At the half way 'twixt thirty and forty.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Twas not much amiss; yet nearest to the last;
How think you then; is not this a wonder,
That a woman lives full seven and thirty years,
Maid to a wife, and wife unto a widow,
Now widowed, and mine own, yet all this while
From the extremest verge of my remembrance,
Even from my weaning hour unto this minute,
Did never taste what was calamity;
I know not yet what grief is, yet have sought
A hundred ways for its acquaintance; with me
Prosperity hath kept so close a watch,
That even those things that I have meant
A cross, have that way turned a blessing;
Is it not strange?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Unparalleled; this gift is singular,
And to you alone belonging; you are the moon,
For there's but one, all women else are stars,
For there are none of like condition:
Full oft, and many have I heard complain
Of discontents, thwarts, and adversities;
But a second to yourself, I never knew
To groan under the superflux of blessings,
To have ever been a lien unto sorrow;
No trip of fate? Sure it is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Ay, sir, 'tis wonderful; but is it well?
For it is now my chief affliction.
I have heard you say, that the child of heaven
Shall suffer many tribulations;
Nay, Kings and princes share them with their subjects;
Then I that know not any chastisement
how may I know my part of childhood?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis a good doubt; but make it not extreme,
'Tis some affliction, that you are afflicted
For want of affliction: cherish that;
Yet wrest it not to misconstruction;
For all your blessings are free gifts from heaven
Health, wealth, and peace; nor can they turn to
Curses, but by abuse. Pray let me question you:
You lost a husband, was it no grief to you?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: It was; but very small; no sooner I
Had given it entertainment as a sorrow,
But straight it turned unto my treble joy;
A comfortable revelation prompts me then,
That husband whom in life I held so dear,
Had changed a frailty to unchanging joys;
Methought I saw him stellified in heaven,
And singing hallelujahs amongst a choir
Of white sainted souls: then again it spoke,
And said; it was a sin for me to grieve
At his best good, that I esteemed best:
And thus this slender shadow of a grief
Vanished again.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: All this was happy; nor can you wrest it
From a heavenly blessing. Do not appoint
The rod: leave still the stroke unto the
Magistrate; the time is not past, but
You may feel enough.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: One taste more I had, although but little,
Yet I would aggravate to make the most
On't: thus 'twas; the other day, it was my hap
In crossing of the Thames,
To drop that wedlock ring from off my finger,
That once conjoined me and my dead husband;
It sunk, I prized it dear; the dearer, 'cause it kept
Still in mine eye the memory of my loss;
Yet I grieved the loss, and did joy withal
That I had found a grief; and this is all
the sorrow I can boast of.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: This is but small.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Nay sure I am of this opinion,
That had I suffered a draught to be made for it,
The bottom would have sent it up again,
I am so wondrously fortunate.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You would not suffer it?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Not for my whole estate.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O mistress, where are you? I think you are the fortunat'st woman, that ever breathed of two shoes: the thief is found.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: The thief; what thief? I never was so happy to be robbed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Bring him away jug; nay, you shall see the strangest
Piece of felony discovered that ever you saw,
Or your great grandmother's grandam before, or after,
A pirate, a water thief.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Bring him away jug; yet the villain would not confess a word till it was found about him.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I think the fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Did you not lose your wedding ring the other day?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Yes sir, but I was not robbed of it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: No; well, thank him that brings it
Home then; and will ask nothing for his pains.
You see this salmon?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Yes, what of it?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: It cost but six pence: but had the fisher known
The worth of it, 'twould have cost you forty shillings.
Is not this your ring?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Your maid Joan examining this salmon, that she
Bought in the market, found that he had swallowed
This gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: How am I vexed with blessings? how think you
sir, is not this above wonder?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I am amazed at it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: First that this fish should snatch it as a bait;
Then that my servant needs must buy that fish
Amongst such infinites of fish and buyers:
What fate is mine that runs all by itself
In unhappy happiness? My conscience dreads it:
Would thou hadst not swallowed it, nor thou not bought it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alas, blame not the poor fish, mistress, he being a phlegmatic
sp.l: Creature, took gold for restorative. He took it fair,
And he that gets gold, let him eat gold.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Nothing can hinder fate.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Seek not to cross it then.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: About your business, you have not pleased me in this.

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.l: By my maidenhead if I had thought you would
Have ta'en it no kindlier, you should ne'er
Have been vexed with sight on't; the garbage should
Have been the cook's fees at this time.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Now do I see the old proverb come to pass;
Give a woman luck, and cast her into th'sea:
There's many a man would wish his wife good
Luck, on that condition he might throw her
Away so. But mistress, there's one within would
Speak with you, that vexeth as fast against
Crosses, as you do against good luck.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I know her sure then, 'tis my gossip foster:
Request her in; here's good company, tell her.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll tell her so for my own credit's sake.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You shall now see an absolute contrary:
Would I had changed bosoms with her for a time,
'T would make me better relish happiness.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O friend and gossip, where are you? I am
O'er loaden with my griefs, and but in your bosom
I know not where to ease me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I had rather help you to a close, stool,
an't please you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ne'er had woman more sinister fate;
All ominous stars were in conjunction
Even at my birth, and do still attend me.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: This is a perfect contrary indeed.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What ails you woman?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Unless seven witches had set spells about me,
I could not be so crossed, never at quiet
Never happy hour, not a minute's content.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You hurt yourself most with impatience.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, I physicians minister with ease,
Although the patient do receive in pain;
Would I could think but of one joyful hour.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You have had two husbands to my knowledge;
And if you had not one joyful hour between
Both, I would you were hanged i'faith.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Full fourteen years I lived a weary maid,
Thinking no joy till I had got a husband.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: That was a tedious time indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I had one loved me well, and then ere long
I grew into my longing peevishness.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: There was some pleasure ere you came to that.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Then all the kindness that he would apply,
Nothing could please; soon after it he died.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: That could be but little grief.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Then worldly care did so o'erload my weakness,
That I must have a second stay; I chose again,
And there begins my griefs to multiply.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: It cannot be, friend; your husband's kind.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A man of fair condition, well reputed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: But it may be he has not that should please her.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Peace sirrah: how can your sorrows increase from him?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: How can they but o'erwhelm me? he keeps a son
That makes my state his prodigality;
To him a brother, one of the city scandals;
The tone the hand, the tother is the maw;
And between both my goods are swallowed up;
the full quantity that I brought amongst 'em
Is now consumed to half.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: The fire of your spleen wastes it;
Good sooth gossip, I could laugh at thee, and only grieve
I have not some cause of sorrow with thee:
Prithee be temperate, and suffer.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis good counsel mistress, receive it so.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Canst thou devise to lay them half on me,
And I'll bear 'em willingly.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Would I could, that I might laugh another while:
But you are wise to heed at others harms;
You'll keep you happy in your widowhood.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Not I in good faith, were I sure marriage
Would make me unhappy.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Try, try, you shall not need to wish;
You'll sing another song, and bear a part
In my grief's descant, when you're vexed at heart:
Your second choice will differ from the first:
So oft as widows marry they are accursed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ay, cursed widows are; but if they had all stiff husbands
To tame 'em, they'd be quiet enough.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You'll be gone sir, and see dinner ready.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I care not if I do mistress, now my stomach's ready;
Yet I'll stay a little and be but to vex you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: When go you, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I will not go yet.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, thou makest me laugh at thee; prithee stay,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay then I'll go to vex you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: You have a light heart gossip.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: So should you woman, would you be ruled by me:
Come, we'll dine together, after walk abroad
Unto my suburb garden, where if thou'lt hear,
He read my heart to thee, and thou from thence
Shalt learn to vex thy cares with patience.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter host Boxall, Stephen, Jack, Dick, Hugh.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Welcome still my merchants of bona Speranza;
sp.p: What's your traffic bullies? What aware deal you in?
sp.l: Cards, dice, bowls, or pigeon-holes; sort 'em
Yourselves; either passage, Novum, or mumchance?
Say my brave bursmen, what's your recreation?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Dice mine host: is there no other room empty?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not a hole unstopped in my house, but this my thrists.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Miscall us not for our money, good mine host, we are
None of your thrifts; we have scaped that scandal long ago.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: Yes, his thrifts we are Jack, though not our own.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Tush, you are young men, 'tis too soon to thrive yet:
He that gathers young, spends when he's old:
'Tis better to begin ill, and end well, than to
Begin well and end ill: miserable fathers have
For the most part unthrifty sons; leave not
Too much for your heirs, boys.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: He says well i'faith; why should a man trust
To executors.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: As good trust to hangmen as to executors:
Who's in the bowling alley mine host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Honest traders, thrifty lads, they are rubbing on't;
Towardly boys, every one strives to lie nearest the mistress.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Give's a bail of dice.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Here my brave wags.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: We fear no counters now mine host, so
Long as we have your bail so ready.
Come, trip.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Up with's heels.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: Down with them.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Now the dice are mine; set me now a fair
Board; a fair passage sweet bones. Boreas.

div.stage: A noise below in the bowling alley, betting, rubbing and wrangling.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How now my fine trundletayles;
My wooden cosmographers:
My bowling alley in an uproar?
Is Orlando up in arms? I must be stickler;
I am constable, justice, and beadle in mine
Own house, I accuse, sentence, and punish:
Have amongst you; look to my box boys;
He that breaks the peace, I break his pate
For recompense; look to my box, I say.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: A pox o'your box, I shall ne'er be so happy to reward it better; set me fair; aloft now.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Out.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: What wast?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: Two treys, and an ace.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Seven still, pox on't; that number of the
Deadly sins haunts me damnably; come sir, throw.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Prithee invoke not so, all sinks too fast already.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: It will be found again in mine host's box.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: In still, two thieves and choose thy fellow.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Take the miller.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Have at them i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: For a thief I'll warrant you, who'll you have next.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Two quatres and a trey.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I hope we shall have good cheer, when two
Cators, and a trey go toth' market.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: So all's whist; they play upon the still pipes now,
The bullbeggar comes when I show my head,
Silence is a virtue, and I have made 'em virtuous,
Let 'em play still till they be penny less; pawn
Till they be naked, so they be quiet, welcome,
And welcome.
How now, how now, my roaring Tamberlaine, take
heed the soldan comes; and 'twere not for profit,
Who would live amongst such bears? why ursa
Major I say, what in capite draconis? is there
No hope to reclaim you, shall I never live in quiet
For you?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Good mine host still 'em: civil gamesters cannot play for 'em.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I come amongst you, you maledictious slaves; I'll
Utter you all; some I'll take ready money for, and lay
Up the rest in the stocks: look to my box, I say.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Your box is like your belly mine host, it
Draws all; now for a suit of apparel.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: At whose suit I pray? you're out again with the threes.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Foot, I think my father threw three when I was
Begotten; pox on't, I know now why I am so
Haunted with threes.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Why, I prithee?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I met the third part of a knave as I came.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: The third part of a knave, 'sfoot what thing's that?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Why a sergeant's yeoman, man; the supervisor himself
Is but a whole one, and he shares but a groat in the
Shilling with him.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: That's but the third part indeed: but goes he no further.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: No, he rests there.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Come, let's give o'er.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I thank you sir, and so much a looser? there's but
The waist-band of my suit left: now sweet bones.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Twelve at all.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Soft, this die is false.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: False? you do him wrong sir, he's true to his master.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Fullum:

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: I'll be hanged then: where's Putney than I pray you

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: 'Tis false, and I'll have my money again.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: You shall have cold iron with your silver then.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Ay, have at you sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I think he's here, sir.

div.stage: Young Foster assists his uncle and the host, and beat see them off; enter the bowlers and steal away their cloaks.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am sure he's now, sir.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Hold, hold, and you be gentlemen hold.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Get you gone varlets, or there's hold to be taken.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Nay sweet sir, no bloodshed in my house; I am lord of misrule, pray you put up, sir.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: 'Sfoot mine host, where are our cloaks?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why, this is quarrelling; make after in time:
Some of your own crew, to try the weight has
Lifted them; look out I say.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: There will ever be thieves in a dicing house
Till thou beest hanged I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Mine host, my cloak was lined through with
Orange tawny velvet.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How, your cloak? I ne'er knew thee worth one.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: You're a company of coney-catching rascals;
Is this a suit to walk without a cloak in?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Uncle, is this the reformation that you promised me?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Coz, shall I tell thee the truth; I had diminished
But six pence of the forty shillings by chance meeting with a
Friend, I went to a tailor, bargained for a suit, it
Came to full forty, I tendered my xxxix and a half,
And do you think the scabby-wristed rascal would
Trust me for six pence.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your credit is the better, uncle.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Pox on him, if the tailor had been a man, I had
Had a fair suit on my back, so venturing for
The tother tester

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You lost the whole bedstead.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: But after this day, I protest coz, you shall never
See me handle those bones again; this day I
Break up school: if ever you call me unthrift after
This day, you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I should be glad to wrong you so, uncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: And what says your father yet, coz?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'll tell you that in your ear.

div.stage: Enter mistress Foster, widow and clown.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Nay, I pray you friend bear me company a little
This way, for into this dicing house I saw my good
Son in law enter, and 'tis odds but he meets his
Uncle here.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You cannot tire me gossip in your company, 'tis the best
Affliction I have to see you impatient.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, ay, you may make mirth of my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: We have hunted well, mistress; do you not see
The hare's in sight?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Did not I tell you so; ay, ay, there's good counsel
Between you, the tone would go afoot to hell,
The other the horse-way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Mother, I am sorry you have trod this path.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Mother? hang thee wretch, I bore thee not, but
Many afflictions I have born for thee; wert thou
Mine own, I'd see thee stretched a handful, and
Put thee a cousin into the cart, ere thou shouldst vex
Me thus.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Were I your own, you could not use me worse than you do.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I'll make thy father turn thee out for ever, or else
I'll make him wish him in his grave; you'll witness
With me gossip where I have found him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay, I'll be sworn upon a book of callico for that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: It shall not need, I'll not deny that I was with my uncle.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: And that shall disinherit thee, if thy father
Be an honest man; thou hadst been better to have
Been born a viper, and eat thy way through thy
Mother's womb into the world, than to tempt my
Displeasure.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou liest Xanthippe; it had been better thou hadst
Been pressed to death under two Irish rugs, than to
Ride honest Socrates thy husband thus, and abuse his
Honest child.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Out raggamuffin, dost thou talk? I shall see thee
in Ludgate again shortly.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Thou liest again, 'twill be at More-gate, beldame, where I shall see thee in the ditch dancing in a cucking-stool.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I'll see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou liest again.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay sir, you do wrong to give a woman so many lies,
She had rather have had twice so many standings, than
One lie.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I'll lie with him I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You'll be a whore then.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Little less I promise you, if you lie with him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: If you complain upon mine honest coz,
And that his father be offended with him,
The next time I meet thee, though it be i'th' street,
The dance i'the dirt upon thy velvet cap;
Nay worse, plestaine thy ruff; nay worse than that,
I'll do thus:

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O my heart gossip, do you see this? Was ever
Woman thus abused?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Methinks 'tis good sport i'faith.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, I am well recompensed to complain to you,
Had you such a kindred.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I would rejoice in't gossip.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Do so; choose here then; o my heart! But I'll do
Your errand; o that my nails were not pared! But I'll do
Your errand; will you go gossip?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: No I'll stay awhile and tell 'em out with patience.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I cannot hold a joint still; dost wisp me, thou
Tatterdemalion; I'll do your errands, if I have a
Husband; o that I could spit wild fire!
My heart, o my heart! If it does not go pantle,
Pantle, pantle in my belly, I am no honest woman:
But I'll do your errands.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Kind gentlewoman, you have some patience.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I have too much sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You may do a good office, and make yourself a peaceful moderator betwixt me and my angry
Father, whom his wife hath moved to spleen against me.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Sir, I do not disallow the kindness your
Consanguinity renders, I would not teach
You otherwise; I'd speak with your uncle, sir,
If you'll give me leave.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You may talk with me sir, in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: With me would you talk, gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Yes sir, with you; you are a brave unthrift.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Not very brave neither; yet I make a shift

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: When you have a clean shirt.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll be no pupil to a woman; leave your discipline.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Nay, pray you hear me sir, I cannot chide.
I'll but give you good counsel; 'tis not a good
Course that you run.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yet I must run to'th' end of it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I would teach you a better, if you'd stay where you are.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I would stay where I am, if I had any money.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: In the dying house?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I think so too, I have played at passage all
This while, now I'd go to hazard.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Dost thou want money? Thou art worthy to be tattered
Hast thou no wit now thy money's gone?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Tis all the portion I have;
I have nothing to maintain me but my wit;
My money is too little I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I cannot believe thy wit's more than thy money,
A fellow so well limbed, so able to do good service,
And want.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why mistress, my shoulders were not made for a frock
And a basket, nor a coal-sack neither, no nor
My hands to turn a trencher at a table's side.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I like that resolution well; but how comes it
Then, that thy wit leaves thy body unfurnished?
Thou art very poor?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: The fortune of the dice you see.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: They are the only wizards, I confess,
The only fortune-tellers; but he that goes to
Seek his fortune from them, must never hope
To have a good destiny allotted him: yet it is
Not the course that I dislike in thee, but that
Thou canst not supply that course, and out -
Cross them that cross thee; were I as thou art

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You'd be as beggarly as I am.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I'll be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Nay, you must be well hanged ere you can be as I am.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: So sir, I conceit you; were I as well hanged then
As you could imagine, I would tell some rich widow
Such a tale in her ear.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha? Some rich widow? By this penniless pocket,
I think 'twere not the worst way.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I'd be ashamed to take such a fruitless oath:
I say, seek me out some rich widow; promise
Her fair; she's apt to believe a young man;
Marry her, and let her estate fly; no matter,
'Tis charity; twenty to one some rich miser raked
It together; this is none of Hercules' labours.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha? let me recount these articles: seek her out;
Promise her fair; marry her; let her estate fly:
But where should I find her?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: The easiest of all: why man, they are more common
Than tavern bushes; two fairs might be
Furnished every week in London with 'em, though no
Foreigners came in, if the charter were granted once:
Nay, 'tis thought, if the horse-market be removed, that
Smithfield shall be so employed, and then I'll
Warrant you 'twill be as well furnished with widows as
'Twas with sows, cows, and old trotting jades before.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Sfoot, if it were, I would be a chapman; I'd see for
My pleasure, and buy for my love, for money I have none.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Thou shalt not stay the market; if thoul't be ruled,
I'll find thee out a widow, and help in some of
The rest too; if thou'lt but promise me the last, but
to let her estate fly: for she's one I love not, and
I'd be glad to see that revenge on her.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Spend her estate, were't five aldermen's; I'll put you
In security for that, sfoot all my neighbours shall be bound
For me, nay, my kind sister in law shall pass her word
For that.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Only this I'll enjoin you, to be matrimonially honest
To her for your own health's sake: all other injuries
Shall be blessings to her.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll bless her then; I ever drunk so much,
That I was never great feeder; give me drink,
And my pleasure, and a little flesh serves my turn.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I'll show thee the party; what sayest thou to myself?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yourself, gentlewoman, I would it were no worse;
I have heard you reputed a rich widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I have a lease of thousands at least, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll let out your leases for you, if you'll allow me
The power I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: That's my hope sir; but you must be honest withal.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll be honest with some; if I can he honest with all,
I will too.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Give me thy hand; go home with me, I'll give
The better clothes; and as I like thee then, we'll
Go further, we may chance make a blind
Bargain of it.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I can make no blind bargain, unless I be
In your bed, widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: No, I bar that sir, let's begin honestly, howe'er
We end; marry for the waste of my estate
Spare it not; do thy worst.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll do bad enough, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Come, will you walk, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No widow, I'll stand to no hazard of blind
Bargains; either promise me marriage, and give
Me earnest in a handfast, or I'll not budge
A foot.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: No sir, are you grown so stout already?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll grow stouter when I am married.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I hope thou'lt vex me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll give you cause I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I shall rail, and curse thee I hope; yet I'd
Not have thee give over neither; for I would
Be vexed; here's my hand, I am thine, thou art mine,
I'll have thee withal faults.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You shall have one with some, and you have me,

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Here's witness, come hither sir.
Cousin, I must call you shortly; and you
Sirrah, be witness to this match; here's man and wife.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I joy at mine uncle's happiness, widow.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I do forbid the banes: alas poor Shagrag,
My mistress does but gull him; you may
Imagine it to be twelve-day at night, and the
Bean found in the corner of your cake, but
'Tis not worth a fetch I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You'll let me dispose of myself, I hope.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You love to be merry mistress; come, come,
Give him four farthings, and let him go.
He'll pray for his good dame, and be drunk;
Why, if your blood does itch that way, we'll
Stand together; how think you? I think here
Is the sweeter bit, you see this nap, and you
See this louse, you may crack of your choice,
If you choose here.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You have put me to my choice then; see, here I choose?
This is my husband: thus I begin the contract.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Tis sealed, I am thine; now coz fear no black
Storms; if thy father thunder, come to me for shelter.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: His word is now a deed, sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I thank you both. Uncle, what my joy conceives,
I cannot utter yet.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I will make black Monday of this: e'er I suffer
This disgrace, the kennel shall run with blood and rags,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, I am your apposite.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I have nothing to say to you, sir; I aim at your uncle

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He has no weapon.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: That's all one, I'll take him as I find him:

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I have taken him so before you, sir; will you be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou shalt take me so too Hodge, for I'll be thy fellow,
Though thy mistress's husband. Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll make you seek your fingers among the dogs,
If you come to me; my fellow? You lousy
Companion; I scorn thee. 'sfoot, is't come to this?
Have I stood all this while to my mistress, an honest,
Handsome, plain-dealing, serving-creature; and she to
Marry a Worson Tittere tu tatter with never a good rag
About him? Stand thou to me, and be my friend; and since
My mistress has forsaken me:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Twas well you came in good time.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I was going the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But tell me one thing, I apprehend not; why didst
Lay thy cap upon the sword's point?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Dost not thou know the reason of that? why, 'twas
To save my belly: dost thou think I am so mad to
Cast myself away for e'er a woman o 'em all,
I'll see 'em hanged first.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come Roger, will you go?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, since there is no remedy, o tears be you my friend!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, prithee Roger do not cry.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I cannot choose; nay I will steep
Mine eyes in crying tears, and crying weep.

div.head: Actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter alderman Bruine, sir Godfry Speedwell, Innocent lambskin, and mistress Jane.

sp.speaker: Bruine.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you're welcome; that once well pronounced
Has a thousand echoes; let it suffice, I have spoke
It to the full: here's your affairs, here's your merchandise,
This is your prize, if you can mix your names and gentle
Bloods with the poor daughter of a citizen.
I make the passage free, to greet and court,
Traffic the mart of love, clap hands and strike
The bargain through, (She pleased) and I shall like.

sp.speaker: God. Sp.
sp.l: 'Tis good ware believe me, sir, I know that by mine
Own experience; for I have handled the like
Many times in my first wife's days, ay, by knighthood,
Sometimes before I was married too; therefore I
Know't by mine own experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Well sir, I know by observation, as much as you do
By experience; for I have known many gentlemen
Have taken up such ware as this is, but it has lyen
On their hands as long as they lived; this I
Have seen by observation.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I am like to have a couple of fair chapmen:
If they were at my own dispose, I would
Willingly rifle them both at twelve pence a share; they
Would be good food for a new plantation; the
Tone might mend his experience; and the other his
Observation very much.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir, let me advise you: I see you want experience,
Meddle no further in this case, 'twill be the
More credit for your observation; for I find by my
Experience, you are but shallow.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: But shallow sir? Your experience is a little wide;
You shall find I will be as deep in this case as
Yourself; my observation has been, where your
Experience must wait at door; yet I will
Give you the fore horse place, and I will be in the
Fills, because you are the elder tree, and I the
Young plant; put on your experience, and I will
Observe.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sweet virgin, to be prolix and tedious , fits no
Experience; short words and large deeds are
Best pleasing to women.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: So, sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: My name is Speedwell, by my father's copy.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Then you never served for't it seems.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Yes, sweet feminine, I have served for it too:
For I have found my nativity suited to my name,
As my name is Speedwell, so have I sped
Well in divers actions.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: It must needs be a fair and comely suit then.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: You observe very well, sweet virgin; for his
Nativity is his doublet, which is the upper part
Of his suit; and his name is in's breeches, for
That part which is his name, he defiles many times.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Your observation is corrupt, sir; let me show mine
Own tale; I say, sweet beauty, my name is
Speedwell, my godfather by his bounty being an
Old soldier, and having served in the wars as far as
Bulloyne, therefore called my name Godfrey; a
Title of large renown; my wealth and wit has
Added to those, the paraphrase of knighthood;
So that my name in the full longitude is called
Sir Godfrey Speedwell, a name of good experience.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: If every quality you have be as large in relation as
Your name sir, I should imagine the best of them, rather
Than hear them reported.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: You say well, sweet modesty, a good imagination is good,
sp.l: And shows your good experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Nay, if names can do any good, I beseech you observe
Mine; my name is Lambskin, a thing both hot and harmless.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: On sir, I would not interrupt you, because you should be brief.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: My godfather seeing in my face some notes of disposition,
sp.l: In my cradle did give me the title of innocent, which I
Have practised all my life time; and since my father's
Decease, my wealth has purchased me in the vanguard
Of my name, the paraphrase of gentility; so that
I am called master innocent Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: In good time; and what trade was your father, sir?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: My father was of an occupation before he was a
Tradesman; for, as I have observed in my fathers
And mother's report, they set up together in
Their youth; my father was a starch-maker, and my
Mother a laundress; so being partners, they did
Occupy long together before they were married;
Then was I born.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: What, before your father was married?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Truly a little after, I was the first fruits, as they say;
Then did my father change his copy, and set up
A brewhouse.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I then came your wealth in, sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Your observation's good; I have carried the tallies
At my girdle seven years together with much
Delight and observation; for I did ever love to
Deal honestly in the nick.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: A very innocent resolution.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Your experience may see his course education; but to
The purpose, sweet female; I do love that
Face of yours.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Sir, if you love nothing but my face, I cannot sell it
From the rest.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: You may see his slender observation; sweet virgin,
I do love your lower parts better than your face.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir you do interrupt, and thwart my love.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I sir, I am your rival; and I will thwart your love ▪
For your love licks at the face, and my love
Shall be arsy-varsy to yours.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I would desire no better wooing of so bad suitors.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Mistake me not kind heart.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: He calls you tooth drawer by way of experience.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: In loving your face, I love all the rest of your body
As you shall find by experience.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Well sir, you love me then?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Let your experience make a trial.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: No sir, I'll believe you rather, and I thank you for't.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I love you too, fair maid, double and treble,
If it please you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I thank you too sir; I am so much beholding
To you both; I am afraid I shall never requite it.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Requite one, sweet chastity, and let it be
Sir Godfrey, with the correspondency of your
Love to him; I will maintain you like a lady,
And it is brave, as I know by experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I will maintain you like a gentlewoman: and
That may be better maintenance than a lady's,
As I have found by observation.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: How dare you maintain that, sir?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I dare maintain it with my purse, sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: I dare cross it with my sword sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: If you dare cross my purse with your sword sir,
I'll lay an action of suspicion of felony to you;
That's flat, sir.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Nay, pray you gentlemen do not quarrel,
Till you know for what.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O, no quarrelling, I beseech you gentlemen!
The reputation of my house is soiled, if any
Uncivil noise arise in't.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Let him but shake his blade at me, and I'll
Throw down my purse, and cry a rape; I
Scorn to kill him, but I'll hang his knighthood,
I warrant him, if he offer assault and battery on
My purse ▪

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay, good sir, put up your sword.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: You have confined him prisoner forever,
I hope your experience sees he's a harmless thing.

sp.speaker: G●●.
sp.l: Sir, here's young master foster requests
To speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Does he? Prithee request him. Gentlemen,
Please you taste the sweetness of my garden
A while, and let my daughter bear you company.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Where she is leader, there will be followers.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: You send me to the galleys, sir; pray you redeem
Me as soon as you can; these are pretty
Things for mirth, but not for serious uses.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Prithee be merry with them then a while,
If but for courtesy; thou hast wit enough;
But take heed they quarrel not.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Nay I dare take in hand to part 'em without
Any danger; but I beseech you let me not
Be too long a prisoner. Will you walk gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: If it please you to place one of us for your conduct,
Otherwise this old coxcomb and I shall quarrel.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Sir Godfrey, you are the eldest; pray lead the way.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Withal my heart, sweet virgin; ah, ha; this place
Promises well in the eyes of experience; master
Innocent, come you behind.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Right sir; but I put the gentlewoman before, and that
Is the thing I desire
And there your experience halts a little.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: When I look back, sir, I see your nose behind.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Then when I look back, your nose stands here.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sweet lady, follow experience,

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: And let observation follow you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: So, now request you master foster in, George; but hark;
Does that news hold his own still, that our ships
Are so near return, as laden on the downs
with such a wealthy fraughtage.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes sir, and the next tide purpose to put into the river:
Master foster, your partner, hath now received more
Such intelligence, with most of the particulars
Of your merchandise, your venture is returned
With treble blessing.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Let him be ever blessed that sent. George now call
In the young man; and hark ye, George, from him
Run to my partner, and request him to me, this
News I'm sure makes him a joyful merchant;
For my own part, I'll not forget my vow,
This free addition heaven hath lent my state,
As freely back to heaven I'll dedicate.
I marry sir, would this were a third suitor
To my daughter Jane, I should better
Like him than all that's come yet. Now master foster,
Are your father and yourself yet reconciled?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, 'twas my business in your courteous tongue
To put the arbitration, I have again
(Discovered by my mother) relieved my poor uncle,
Whose anger now so great is multiplied,
I dare not venture in the eye of either,
Till your persuasions with fair excuse
Have made my satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Mother a pearl, sir, 'tis a shrewd task;
Yet I'll do my best; your father hath so good news,
That I hope't will be a fair motive to't;
But women's tongues are dangerous stumbling blocks
To lie in the way of peace. Now George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Master foster's coming, sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I beseech you sir, let not me see him, till you
Have conferred with him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well, well, e'er your return to master foster, call my
Daughter forth of the garden.
And how does your uncle, master foster?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, so well, 〈◊〉
Same that shortly will o'erspread 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why I commend thee still,
He wants no good from thee, no not in report:
▪ 'tis well done sir, and you show duty in't.
Now daughter, where are your lusty suitors?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I was glad of my release, sir: suitors call you'm,
I'd keep dish water continually boiling, but I'd
Seethe such suitors; I have had much ado to
Keep 'em from bloodshed; I have seen for all
The world, a couple of cowardly curs quarrel
In that fashion, as t'one turns his head, the
Other snaps behind; and as he turns, his
Mouth recoils again: but I thank my pains
For't, I have leagued with 'em for a week without
Any farther intercourse.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well daughter, well; say a third trouble come;
Say in the person of young master foster here
Came a third suitor: how then?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Three's the woman's total arithmetic in
Deed, I would learn to number no farther,
If there was a good account made of that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I can instruct you so far, sweet beauty.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Take heed, sir; I have had ill handsel today;
Perhaps 'tis not the fortunate season, you were
Best adjourn your journey to some happier time.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: There shall no augurism fright my plain
Dealing: sweet, I fear no hours.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: You'll not betray me with love-powder

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nor with gunpowder neither i'faith; yet I'll
Make you yield if I can.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Go, get you together; your father will be coming;
Leave me with your suit to him, ply this yourself;
And Jane, use him kindly, he shall be his
Father's heir I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Never the more for that, father; if I use him
kindly, it shall be for something I like in him.
Self, and not for any good he borrows of his father,
But come sir, 〈◊〉 walk into the garden; for
That's the field I have best fortune to overcome
My suitors in.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I fear not that fate neither, but if I walk
Into your garden, I shall be tasting your sweets.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Taste sweetly and welcome sir; for there grows
Honesty, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I shall be plucking at your honesty.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: By my honesty but you shall not sir: I'll hold
You a hand full of pennyroyal of that i'faith,
If you touch my honesty there, I'll make you eat
Sorrel to your supper, though I eat sullenwood myself:
No sir, gather first time and sage, and such wholesome
Herbs; and honesty and hearts-ease will ripen
The whilst.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You have fair roses, have you not?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Yes sir, roses; but no gillyflowers.

div.stage: Enter master Foster and his wife.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Go, go, and rest on Venus' violets; show her
A dozen of bachelor's button boy; here comes
His father. Now my kind partner, have we
Good news?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, in a word, take it; your full lading and venture
Is returned at sixty fold increase.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Heaven take the glory; a wondrous blessing;
O keep us strong against these flowing tides!
Man is too weak to bound himself below,
When such high waves do mount him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O sir, care and ambition seldom meet,
Let us be thrifty; titles will faster come,
Than we shall wish to have them.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Faith I desire none.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why sir, if so you please, I'll ease your cares;
Shall I like a full adventurer now bid you
A certain ready sum for your half traffic.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ay, and I'd make you gainer by it too;
For then would I lay by my trouble, and begin
A work which I have promised unto heaven,
A house, a domus dei shall be raised,
Which shall to doomsday be established for succour to
The poor; for in all ages there must be such.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Shall I bid your venture at a venture.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Pray you do sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Twenty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay, than you underrate your own value much;
Will you make it thirty?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Shall I meet you half way?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: I meet you there sir; for five and twenty thousand pounds the full ventures yours.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: If you like my payment, 'tis the one half in ready cash, the other sealed for six months.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis merchant like and fair; George, you
Observe this? Let the contents be drawn.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: They shall sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Your hazard is now all past, sir.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I rejoice at it, sir, and shall not grudge your gains,
Though multiplied to thousands.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: Believe me sir, I account myself a large gainer by you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Much good may it be to you, sir; but one
Thing at this advantage of my love to you
Let me entreat.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What is it, sir?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Faith my old suit, to reconcile those breaches
Twist your kind son and you; let not the love
He shows unto his uncle, be any more a bar
To sunder your blessings and his duty.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I would you had enjoined me some great labour
Far your own love's sake, but to that my
View stands fixed against; I'm deaf,
〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉 of them.
Nay, sir, if you knew all, you would not waste your
words in so vain expense: since his last
Reformation, he has flown out again,
And in my sight relieved his uncle in the
Dicing house; for which, either he shall be no
Father to him, or no husband to me.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Well sir, go call my daughter forth of the
Garden, and bid her bring her friend along
With her, troth sir, I must not leave you thus;
I must needs make him your son again.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, I have no such thing a kin to me.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Look you sir, know you this duty?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Not I sir: he's a stranger to me: save your
Knee, I have no blessing for you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Go, go to your uncle sir; you know where to
Find him, he's at his old haunt, he wants
More money by this time; but I think the
Conduit pipe is stopped from whence it ran.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Did he not say, he'd beg for you, you'd best
Make use of's bounty.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay, good sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, if your daughter cast any eye of favour upon
This unthrift restraint, he's a beggar: mistress
Jane, take heed what you do.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, ay, be wise mistress Jane; do not you trust
To spleen and time worn to pity, you'll
Not find it so; therefore good gentlewoman
Take heed.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay then you are too impenetrable.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, your money shall be ready, and your bills;
Other business I have none: for thee,
Beg, hang, die like a slave;
Such blessings ever thou from me shalt have.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Well sir, I'll follow you; and sir, be comforted,
I will not leave till I find some remorse;
Mean time let not want trouble you;
you shall not know it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Su, 'tis not want I fear, but want of blessing
My knee was bent for; for mine uncle's state,
Which now I dare say outweighs my father's far,
Confirms my hopes as rich, as with my fathers,
His love excepted only.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thy uncle's state, how for heaven's love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: By his late marriage to the wealthiest widow
That London had, who has not only made him
Lord of herself, but of her whole estate.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Mother-a-pearl, I rejoice in't: this news
Is yet but young?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fame will soon speak it loud, sir

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: This may help happily to make all peace;
But how have you parleyed with my daughter, sir.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Very well father: we spoke something, but did
Nothing at all; I requested him to pull me
A Catherine pear, and had not I looked to him
He would have mistaken and given me a poppering;
And to requite his kindness, I plucked him a rose,
And he had almost pricked my finger for my pains.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well said wag, are there sparks kindled, quench
'Em not for me, 'tis not a father's roughness,
Nor doubtful hazard of an uncle's kindness
Can me deter; I must to your father.
Where (As a chief affair) I'll once more move,
And if I can return him back to love.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, you see I have made a speedy choice,
And as swift a marriage; be it as it will,
I like the man, if his qualities afflict me,
I shall be happy in't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I must not distaste, what I have helped to make;
'Tis I that joined you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A good bargain, I hope.
Roger, where's your master?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: The good man of the house is within forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not your master, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Tis hard of digestion: yes, my master is within;
He masters you therefore I must be
Content: you have longed for crosses a good
While, and now you are like to be
Farther off them than e'er you were; for
I'm afraid, your good husband will leave
You ne'er a cross i'th' house to bless you with.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Well sir, I shall be blessed in't: but where is he?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Where he has mistaken the place a little,
Being his wedding-day; he is in nomine,
When he should be in re.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And where's that?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: In your countinghouse; if he were a kind
Husband, he would have been in another
Countinghouse by this time: he's tumbling
Over all his money bags yonder; you shall
Hear of him in the bowling alley again.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why sir, all is his, and at his
Dispose; who shall dare to thwart him?

div.stage: Enter Stephen with bills and bonds.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Look where he comes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How now, sweetheart? what hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I find much debts belonging to you, sweet;
And my care must be now to fetch them in;

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ha, ha; prithee do not mistake thyself,
Nor my true purpose; I did not wed to thrall,
Or bind thy large expense, but rather to add
A plenty to that liberty; I thought by this,
Thou wouldst have stuffed thy pockets full of gold,
And thrown it at a hazard; made ducks and drakes,
And baited fishes with thy silver flies;
Lost, and fetched more: why this had been my joy;
Perhaps at length thou wouldst have wasted
My store; why, this had been a blessing too
Good for me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Content thee, sweet, those days are gone,
Ay, even from my memory;
I have forgotten that e'er I had such follies,
And I'll not call 'em back: my ears are bent
To keep your state, and give you all content.
Roger, go, call your fellow-servants up to me,
And to my chamber bring all books of debt;
I will o'erlook, and cast up all accounts,
That I may know the weight of all my cares,
And once a year give up my stewardship.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Now you may see what hasty matching is;
You had thought to have been vexed, and now
You cannot: you have married a husband,
That, sir reverence of the title, now being my master in law,
I do think he'll prove the miserablest, covetous
Rascal, that ever beat beggar from his gate. But
'Tis no matter; time was when you were fairly
Offered, if you would have taken it; you might have had
Other matches i'faith, if it had pleased you; and those
That would have crossed you; I would have sold away
All that ever you had had; have kept two or three
Whores at livery under your nose; have turned you out
In your smock, and have used you like a woman; where
As now, if you'd hang yourself, you can have none of
These blessings: but 'tis well enough, now you must
Take what follows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I'm new to seek for crosses, the hopes I meant
Turn to despair, and smoother in content.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O nephew are you come: the welcomest wish
That my heart has; this is my kinsman, sweet.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Let him be largely texted in your love,
That all the city may read it fairly;
You cannot remember me, and him forget.
We were alike to you in poverty.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I should have begged that bounty of your love,
Though you had scanted me to have given't him;
for we are one, I an uncle nephew,
He an nephew uncle, but my sweet self,
My slow request you have anticipated
With proffered kindness; and I thank you for it.
But how, kind cousin, does your father use you?
Is your name found again within his books?
Can he read son there?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: 'Tis now blotted quite: for by the violent instigation
Of my cruel stepmother, his vows and oaths
Are stamped against me, ne'er to acknowledge me,
Ne'er to call, or bless me as a child;
But in his brow, his bounty, and behaviour
I read it almost plainly.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Cousin, grieve not at it; that father lost at home,
You shall find here; and with the loss of his inheritance,
You meet another amply proffered you;
Be my adopted son, no more my kinsman;
So that this borrowed bounty do not stray
From your consent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Call it not borrowed, sir, 'tis all your own;
Here 'fore this reverent man I make it known,
Thou art our child as free by adoption,
As derived from us by conception, birth, and
Propinquity; inheritor to our full substance.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You were born to bless us both,
My knee shall practise a son's duty
Even beneath sons, giving you all
The comely dues of parents: yet not
Forgetting my duty to my father;
Where'er I meet him, he shall have my knee,
Although his blessing ne'er return to me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come then my dearest son, I'll now give thee
A taste of my love to thee; be thou my deputy,
The factor and disposer of my business;
Keep my accounts, and order my affairs;
They must be all your own; for you, dear sweet,
Be merry, take your pleasure, at home, abroad;
visit your neighbours; ought that may seem good
To your own will, down to the country ride;
For cares and troubles lay them all aside,
And I will take them up, it's fit that weight
Should now lie all on me: take thou the height
Of quiet and content, let nothing grieve thee;
I brought thee nothing else, and that I'll give thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Will the tide never turn? Was ever woman
Thus burdened with unhappy happiness?
Did I from riot take him, to waste my goods,
And he strives to augment it? I did mistake him.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Spoil not a good text with a false comment;
All these are blessings, and from heaven sent;
It is your husband's good, he's now transformed
To a better shade, the prodigal's returned.
Come, come, know joy, make not abundance scant;
You 'Plain of that which thousand women want.

div.stage: Enter alderman Bruine, master Foster and factors bearing or bags.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: So, so, haste home good lads, and return for the rest.
Would they were covered, George, 'tis too public
Blazon of my estate; but 'tis no matter now;
I'll bring it abroad again ere it be long.
Sir, I acknowledge receipt of my still half debt,
Twelve thousand five hundred pounds; it now remains
You seal those writings, as assurance for the rest,
And I am satisfied for this time.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Pray stay sir, I have bethought me, let me once
Throw dice at all, and either be a complete
Merchant, or wrack my estate for ever:
Hear me sir, I have of wares that are now vendible,
So much as will defray your utmost penny;
Will you accept of them, and save this charge
Of wax and parchment.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He they vendible sir? I am your chapman:
What are they, master foster?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Broad clothes, kerseys, cutchineale, such
As will not stay two days upon your hands.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I find your purpose; you'd have your ware.
Houses empty for the receipt of your full fraught;
I'll be your furtherer, make so your rates, that
I may be no looser.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I have no other end, sir; let our
Factors peruse and deal for both.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Mine is returned; George, here's a new business,
You and Richard must deal for some commodities
Betwixt us, if you find 'em even gain or but
Little loss, take carriage presently and carry 'em home.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: Richard, have you any further news yet from our shipping?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not yet, sir; but by account from the last, when they
Put from Dover, this tide should bring them into
Saint Catherine's pool; the wind has been friendly.

sp.speaker: O, Fost.
sp.l: Listen their arrival, and bid the gunner speak it
In his loud thunder all the city over;
Tingle the merchants ears at the report
Of my abundant wealth; now go with George.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I shall do both, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: I must plainly now confess, master alderman, I shall gain much by you. The half of your ship defrays my full cost.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Beshrew me if I grudge it, being myself a sufficient gainer by my venture, sir.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Still flows the tide of my unhappiness,
The stars shoot mischief, and every hour
Is critical to me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: How now woman? wracked in the heaven of felicity?
sp.l: What ailest thou?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I think the devil's mine enemy

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I hope so too; his hate is better than his friendship.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Your brother, your good brother, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What of him? he's in Ludgate again.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: No, he's in Highgate; he struts it bravely,
An alderman's pace at least.

sp.speaker: O, Fost.
sp.l: Why, these are oracles, doubtful enigmas!

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Why, I'm sure you have heard the news;
He's married forsooth.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: How, married? no woman of repute would choose so slightly.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: A woman, in whose breast, I had thought had lived
The very quintessence of discretion; and who is't,
Think you? nay you cannot guess, though I should give
You a day to riddle it; 'tis my gossip, man, the rich
Widow of Cornhill.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Fie, fie, 'tis fabulous.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Are you my husband? then is she his wife;
How will this upstart beggar shoulder up,
And take the wall of you? his new found pride
Will know no eldership.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: But wife, my wealth will five times double his, ere
This tide ebb again; I wonder I hear not the
Brazen cannon proclaim the arrival of my
Infinite substance.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: But beggars will be proud of little, and shoulder at the best.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Let him first pay his old score, and then reckon;
But that she: —

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, that's it mads me too.
Would any woman, less to spite herself,
So much profane the sacred name of wedlock:
A dove to couple with a stork, or a lamb a viper?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Content thee; forgive her; she'll do so no more;
She was a rich widow, a wife he'll make her poor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
