sp.l: So sir, you have closed it well; if so ill it prove,
Leave it to proof, and wish not misery
Unto your enemy look, here he comes.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: You say true 'tis my enemy indeed.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Save you master alderman, I have some business with you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: With me, sir, and most welcome, I rejoice to see you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Do you observe, sir; he will not know you now?
Jockey's a gentleman now.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Well fare rich widows, when such beggars flourish;
But ill shall they fare, that flourish o'er such beggars.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: He laughs at you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: No wonder, woman, he would do that in Ludgate;
But 'twas when his kind nephew did relieve him:
I shall hear him cry there again shortly.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Oysters, new Walfleet oysters.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: The gentleman is merry.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: No, no, no; he does this to spite me; as who should say, I had been a fishwife in my younger days.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Fie, fie, gentlemen, this is not well;
My ears are guilty to hear such discords.
Look, master foster; turn your eye that way;
There's duty unregarded, while envy struts
In too much state: believe me, gentlemen,
I know not which to chide first.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What idol kneels that heretic too.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Rise boy; thou art now my son, and owest no knee
To that unnatural; I charge you rise.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Do sir, or turn your adoration that way;
You were kind to him in his tattered state;
Let him requite it now.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Do, do, we have paid for't aforehand,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I would I were divided in two halves, so that might reconcile your harsh division

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Proud sir, this son which you have alienated
For my love's sake, shall by my love's bounty
Ride side by side in the best equipage
Your scorns dare pattern him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, ay, a beggar's gallop up and down.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ay, 'tis up now, the next step down.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I laugh at your envy sir, my business is to you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good sir, speak of any thing but this.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Sir, I am furnishing some shipping forth,
And want some English traffic, broad-clothes, kerseys
Or such like, my voyage is to the straits:
If you can supply me, sir, I'll be your chapman.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: That I shall soon resolve you, sir;
Come hither George.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: This is the rich merchantman;

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: That's neither grave not wife;

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Who will kill a man at Tyburn shortly.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: By carts that may arise; or if the hangman die,
He may have his office.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Then you have bargained, George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: And the ware carried home, sir; you must look
To be little gainer; but lose you cannot.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis all I desire from thence, sir I can furnish you
With wares I lately from your brother bought;
Please you go see them, for I would fain divide you,
Since I can win no nearer friendship.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll go with you, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Take your adoption with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I crave but your blessing with me, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: 'Tis my curse then; get thee out of mine eye.
Thou'rt a beam in't, and I'll tear it out e'er it
Offend to look on thee.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Go, go, sir; follow your uncle-father,
Help him to spend, what thrift has got together;
'Twill be charity in you to spend,
Because your charity it was to lend.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My charity; you can a virtue name.
And teach the use, yet never knew the same

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: See wife, here comes Richard.
Now listen, and hear me crowned
The wealthiest London merchant.
Why dost thou look so sadly?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Why dost not speak; hast lost thy tongue?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I never could speak worse.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why, thy voice is good enough.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But the worst accent sir, that ever you heard,
I speak a screech-owl's note. O you have made
The most unhappiest bargain that ever merchant did!

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ha? what can so baleful be, as thou wouldst seem
To make by this sad prologue? I am no traitor
To confiscate my goods: speak, whate'er it be.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I would you could conceit it, that I might not speak it.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Dally not with torments, sink me at once.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now you've spoken it half; 'tis sinking I must treat of
Your ships are all sink.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: O thou fatal raven; let me pull thine eyes out for this
sp.l: Sad croak.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hold woman; hold prithee; 'tis none of his fault.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis thine, thou wretch; and therefore
Let me turn my vengeance all on thee; thou
Hast made hot haste to empty all my warehouses,
And made room for that the sea hath drunk before
Thee.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Undone for ever! Where could this mischief fail ▪
Were not my ships in their full pride at Dover;
And what English Carybda's has the devil digged
To swallow nearer home.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Even in the mouth, and entrance of the Thames
They were all cast away.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Dam up thy mouth from any farther
Mischievous relation.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Some men were saved, but not one pennyworth of goods.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Even now thy baleful utterance was choked,
And now it runs too fast; thou fatal bird no more.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: May serpents breed, and fill this fatal stream,
And poison her for ever.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O curse not, they come too fast!

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Let me curse somewhere, wretch, or else I'll throw
That all on thee; 'tis thou, ungodly slave,
That art the mark unto the wrath of heaven:
I thrived ere I knew thee.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I prithee split me too.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I would I could; I would I had never seen thee;
For I ne'er saw hour of comfort since I knew thee.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Undone for ever, my credit I have cracked,
To buy a venture, which the sea has soaked;
What worse can woe report.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Yes worse than all,
Thy enemies will laugh, and scorn thy fall.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Be it the worst then; that place I did assign
My unthrifty brother, Ludgate, must now be mine.
Break, and take Ludgate.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Take Newgate rather.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I scorned my child, now he may scorn his father.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Scorn him still.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I will; would he my wants relieve,
I'd scorn to take what he would yield to give:
My heart be still my friend, although no other;
I'll scorn the help of either son, or brother,
My portion's begging now; seldom before.
In one sad hour, was man so rich and poor.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter mistress Jane, Godfry Speedewell, and master Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Gentlemen, my father's not within; please
You to walk a turn or two in the garden,
He'll not be long.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: Your father, mistress Jane, I hope you have observation in you,
sp.l: And know our humours; we come not a-wooing to your father.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Experience must bear with folly; thou art all innocent,
sp.l: And thy name is Lambskin; grave sapience guides me,
And I care not a pin for thy squibs, and thy crackers,
My old dry wood shall make a lusty bonfire, when
Thy green chips shall lie hissing in the chimney -
Corner. Remember mistress, I can make you a lady by
Mine own experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Prithee do not stand troubling the gentlewoman
With thy musty sentences, but let her love be laid
Down betwixt us like a pair of cudgels, and into
Whose hands she thrusts the weapons first, let him
Take up the bucklers.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: A match between us

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Must I be stickler then?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: We are both to run at the ring of your setting
Up, and you must tell us who deserves most favour.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: But will you stand both at my disposing?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Else let me never stand but in a pillory.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: You love me both you say?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: By this hand. —

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Hand? Zounds by the four and twenty elements.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Pray spare your oaths; I do believe you do
You would not else make all this stir to woo.
Sir Godfrey, you are a knight both tough and old,
A rotten building cannot long time hold.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Speedwell, live well, die well, and be hanged well.
Revenge your copy well, your experience will not carry it else.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: You're rich too, at least yourself so say;
What though? you're but a gilded man of clay.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: A man of gingerbread; i'faith I could find in
My heart to eat him.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Should I wed you, the fire with frost must marry
January and may; I for a younger tarry.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: That's l; introth I'll be thy young lambskin; thou shalt
Find me as innocent as a sucking dove: speak, sweet
〈◊〉, am I the youth in a basket?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.l: You are the sweet youth sir, whose pretty eyes
Would make me love; but you must first be wise.

sp.speaker: Speede.
sp.l: Ah, hah, is your coxcomb cut? I see experience must
Board this fair pinnace: a word in private,

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I'll have no words in private, unless I hear too.

div.stage: Enter master Bruine, Stephen and Robin.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, we'll make few
Winds about it; merchants in
Bargaining must not, like soldiers lying at a siege, stay
Months, weeks, days, but strike at the first parley.
Broad-clothes, and wools, and other rich commodities, I
Lately from your brother bought, are all your own.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Then be not angry gentle sir,
If now a string be touched, which hath too long
Sounded so harshly over all the city;
I now would wind it to a musical height.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Good master alderman I think that string will still
Ostend mine ear; you mean the jarring
Twixt me and my brother?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: In troth the same.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I hate no poison like that brother's name

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O fie, not so.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Uncivil churl, when all his sails were up.
And that his proud heart danced on golden ways:

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: As heaven be thanked it still does.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yet sir, than I being sunk, and drowned in mine
Own misery, he would not cast out a poor line
Of thread to bring me to the shore; I had been
Dead, and might have starved for him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: A better fate sir, stood at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: True sir; this was he that lifted me from want
And misery, whose cruel father for that
Good cast him away; scorning his name and blood;
Lopped from his side this branch that held me dear.
For which he's now my son, my joy, my heir,
But for his father hang him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: By heaven.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come, come, live in more charity, he is your brother;
If that name offend, I'll sing that tune no more.
Yonder's my daughter busy with her suitors;
We'll visit them. Now Jane, bid your friends
Welcome.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: They must be welcome sir, that come with you;
To thee ten thousand welcomes still are due.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Lounds sir knight, we have stood beating the bush
And the bird's flown away; this city
Bowler has kissed the mistress at first cast.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: How fare ye gentlemen, what cheer sir knight?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: An adventurer still sir, to this new found land.

sp.speaker: Lamb
sp.l: He sails about the point sir, but he cannot put in yet.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The wind may turn sir. A word master foster.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: You see sir Speedwell, what card is turned
Up for trump; I hold my life this spruce
Citizen will forestall the market, o
These brisk factors, are notable firkers.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: I doubt sir, he will play the merchant with us.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They both are suitors sir, yet both shoot wide;
my daughter sure must be your kinsman's bride.
I'll give her a wedding ring on that condition
And put a stone in't worth a thousand pound, sir.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You have my hand and heart to't, be she pleased so.

sp.speaker: Lamb
sp.p: 'Sfoot, let's show ourselves gallants, or gallimaufies :
sp.l: Shall we be buried by a cockney. A word
My fair 〈◊〉; do you see sir, here be those
That have gone a fishing, and can give you a
Gudgeon.
You were best go fish for better manners, or I
Shall bob for ●les with you.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Zounds are you a striker? Draw, sir knight.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Not in my house; I pray be quiet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He dares not do't abroad believe me, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Now by my life my boy, for this brave spirit
●g thee in mine arms: lose life and limbs
Ere thou forsake thy love.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: He's no rival here sir; has struck me,
And we are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And hear ye, sir, let him seek out his equals;
For some of us are in danger to make her
A lady shortly: I know what I speak; what
I speak, I'll do; yet I'll do nothing, but
What comes from grave experience.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Speak what you please sir, he's a gentleman as
Good at either of you both, and shall in lists of
Love for such a bedfellow, brave him that dares,
And here lay down more gold to win her love,
Than both your states are worth.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Ha? do you know us, sir? You grow too bold;
My experience now hath found you;
You were once a tattered fellow, your name is
Foster; have you such gold to give?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Yes, yes, has won it betting at the bowling alleys,
Or at the pigeon-holes in the garden alleys.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You are ●uddy grooms to upbraid me with that scorn,
which virtue now gilds over; pray ye gentlemen
May I request your names.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Our names are in the herald's books I warrant you
My name is innocent Lambskin; and this knight,
Simply though he stands here, is known to be
Sir Godfrey Speedwell.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Well may he speed sir; Lambskin and Speedwell,
Ha? Is't so? I think I shall give you a medicine
To purge this itch of love, sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: No itch neither sir, we have no scabs here,
But yourself and your cousin.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Very good sir, my little lambskin. I have you
Here in sheepskin; look you, 'tis so i'faith.
See, master alderman, these two cracked gallants
Are in several bonds to my predecessor
For a debt of full two thousand apiece.
Cousin, fetch me a sergeant straight.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: O let him, I have a protection, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll try that, sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: A sergeant? Nay, than experience must work,
Legs be strong and bold; when sergeants wait
At feasts, the cheer's but cold.
I'll shift for one.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Knight, knight; 'sfoot if an errand knight
Run away, I were an errand ass to tarry,
And be catched in the limebush: I love the
Wench well; but if they have no hole to
Place me in, but the hole in the counter,
I'll be gone and leave 'em; that's flat

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You have scared the suitors from the mark, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I am glad on't sir; they are but such as seek
To build their rotten state on you, and with your
Wealth to underprop their weakness;
Believe me, reverend sir, I had much rather
You'd venture that my coz might call you father.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: We'll talk of that anon; see sir,
Here comes your wife, the theme
Of all her time, with goodness mixed, the happy
Woman that was never vexed; you're welcome
Mrs Foller.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Wife, your two debtors were here but now;
And Lambskin; a wolf could not have torn
〈◊〉 Lambskin worse, than the bare name
Of a Serjeant: the very thought made them both
To take their heels and run away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas, they are poor and lean, and being so;
Kill them not till they are fatter.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: At thy girdle, sweet, hangs the keys, to
Lock the prison doors or let them lose:
'Twas 〈◊〉 my intent only in way of mirth to
Rid them from the presence of mistress Jane,
That our adopted son might have no bar
Unto his love.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: The match is fair; and were that knot once tied,
I'd send some angels to attend the bride.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Sir, here's your factor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Are the wares ready.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes, and delivered sir, to master Foster's servants,
Who conveyed them in carts to the custom.
House, there to be shipped; but going with them,
Sir, I met ill news.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ill news? what is't?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Old master Foster's ships so richly laden,
By strange misfortune, sir, are cast away.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Now heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How? cast away; where?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible; they rid at Dover safe,
When he outbought my full share in the fraught,
And paid me down near thirty thousand pounds
in wares and money.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Which had he not done, you had lost your venture:
By master Foster's own appointment sir, they weighed
Their anchors up, and so to come for London;
But by a merciless storm they all were
Swallowed, even in the Thames' mouth; yet
The men were saved, but all the goods were lost.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my poor father! This loss will break his back.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha? What's that to you? if in my favour you'll
Sit warm, then bury all love to him,
Nay duty, hear you sir? What sheddest thou tears
For him, that had no care to see thy heart drop
Blood? he was unnatural, and heaven hath
Justly now rewarded him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis a most strange fate; he needs would buy my
Part at any rate, he cared not what; and now all's lost,

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Greedy desire he swallowed, and now is swallowed:
'Tis but his hire; and I'll not pity it, no more
Than he, in his abundance, did my misery.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I grieve for my poor gossip, his good wife,
She never met good fortune all her life,
And this will break her heartstrings:
In good sooth I'll go and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: In good sooth you shall not,
Nor him, nor her at this time, gentle wife;
He scorned me in his height, now being poor,
If that he needs my help, he knows my door.
Sir, we'll for this time leave you, at fitter leisure,
We'll have this marriage talked of.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: At your own good pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come wife; go not to see your father, sir, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Jane, bring your friends toth' door.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'll help my father, though myself grow poor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Where's my factor?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What, are the square stones, and timber
Brought as I appointed?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes, sir, and the workmen, that daily ply the
Work, are in number fourscore at least.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: My vows flew up to heaven, that I would make
Some pious work in the brass book of fame,
That might till doomsday lengthen out my name.
Near Norton Folgate therefore have I bought
Ground to erect this house, which I will call
And dedicate, saint Marie's hospital;
And when 'tis finished, o'er the gates shall stand
In capital letters, these words fairly graven
For I have given the work and house to heaven
And called it, domus dei, god's house;
For in my zealous faith I know full well,
Where good deeds are, there heaven itself doth dwell.

div.stage: Enter old Foster, Richard his factor, and the keeper of Ludgate

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Good sir, resolve not thus; return again,
Your debts are not so great, that you should yield
Your body thus to prison unconstrained.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I will not trust the iron hearts of men;
My credit's lost, my wealth the sea has swallowed,
Wracked at my door, even in the mouth o'th' Thames.
O my misfortune! never man like me
Was so thrown down, and cast to misery.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Dear sir, be patient.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I prithee get thee gone, and with thy diligence
Assist thy mistress to keep that little left, to
Help herself, whilst here in Ludgate I secure
My body from writs, arrests, and executions,
Which, well I know, my cruel creditors will
Thunder on me. Go, get thee gone; if what
Is left they'll take, do thou agree;
If not, I am here resolved to stay and die.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'll do my best sir, to procure your peace.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Do so, come sir, I yield myself your prisoner,
You are the keeper of this Ludgate.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Yes sir, your name is registered among the prisoners.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: So, I have seen the fair outside of this tomb before;
this goodly apple has a rotten core.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: As all prisons have, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I prithee bar me of no privilege due to a free
Citizen; thou knowest me well?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Yes master foster, and I sorrow for your losses,
Yet doubt not but your son and brother.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O speak not of them! do not kiss and kill me:
I have no son nor brother that esteems me,
And I for ever hate their memory:
Prithee no more; I am come sick into a
Bad inn, and look for worse attendance,
I have taken a surfeit of misfortunes, and here
Must swallow pills
With poison to recure me: I am sea-sick, sir,
And heave my hands to heaven; ne'er to so
Low an ebb was foster driven.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: There be some fees to pay, sir, at your coming in.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: So, so, if this old walnut-tree, after all this
Cudgelling, have but one cluster left, thou shalt
Have that too; if not, take off these leaves that
Cover me; pull off these white locks; rend them from
My head, and let me in my woes be buried.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Alas, sir, this house is poor.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I think no less;
For rich men seldom meet with such distress,
Well, well, what book must I read over now?
What servile oar must I be tied to here,
Slave-like to tug within this christian galley?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Sir, being the youngest prisoner in the house,
You must beg at the iron grate above,
As others do for your relief and theirs.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: For a beggar to beg, sir, is no shame;
And for the iron grate, it bears an emblem
Of iron-hearted creditors, that force men lie
In loathsome prisons thus to starve and die.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Who would you speak with, sir?
O, cry you mercy; 'tis his son:
I'll leave them.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O torment to my soul! What mak'st thou here?
Cannot the picture of my misery
Be drawn, and hung out to the eyes of men,
But thou must come to scorn and laugh at it?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Dear sir, I come to thrust my back under your load,
To make the burden lighter.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hence from my sight, dissembling villain; go,
Thine uncle sends defiance to my woe,
And thou must bring it: hence, thou basilisk,
That kill'st me with mine eyes: nay, never kneel;
These scornful mocks more than my woes I feel.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alas, I mock ye not; but come in love,
And natural duty sir, to beg your blessing;
And for mine uncle —

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Him, and thee I curse,
Pl starve, e'er I eat bread from his purse,
Or from thy hand; out villain, tell that cur,
Thy barking uncle, that I lie not here
Upon my bed of riot, as he did,
Covered with all the villainies, which man
Had ever woven; tell him I lie not so,
It was the hand of heaven struck me thus low,
And I do thank it. Get thee gone, I say,
Or I shall curse thee, strike thee; prithee away;
Or if thou'lt laugh thy fill at my poor state,
Then stay, and listen to the prison grate,
And hear thy father, an old wretched man,
That yesterday had thousands, beg and cry,
To get a penny: o my misery!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Dear sir, for pity hear me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Upon my curse I charge no nearer come,
I'll be no father to so vild a son.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my abortive fate!
Why for my good am I thus paid with hate?
From this sad place of Ludate here I freed
an uncle, and I lost a father for it;
Now is my father here, whom if I succour,
I then must lose my uncle's love and favour.
My father once being rich, and uncle poor,
I him relieving was thrust forth of doors;
Baffled, reviled, and disinherited:
Now mine own father here must beg for bread,
Mine uncle being rich, and yet if I
Feed him, myself must beg. O misery,
How bitter is thy taste! yet I will drink
Thy strongest poison; fret what mischief can,
I'll feed my father, though, like the pelican,
I peck mine own breast for him.

div.stage: Old Foster, and above at the grate, a box hanging down.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread, one penny to buy a
Loaf of bread for the tender mercy!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O me my shame! I know that voice full well;
I'll help thy wants, although thou curse me still.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread; some Christian man send back
Your charity to an number of poor prisoners;
One penny for the tender mercy.
The hand of heaven reward you, gentle sir,
Never may you want, never feel misery;
Let blessings in unnumbered measure grow,
And fall upon your head where'er you go.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O happy comfort! curses to the ground
First struck me, now with blessings I am crowned.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread, for the tender mercy; one
Penny for a loaf of bread.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Pl buy more blessings; take thou all my store,
I'll keep no coin; and see my father poor.

sp.speaker: O. Fost,
sp.l: Good angels guard you, sir, my prayers shall be
That heaven may bless you for this charity.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: If he knew me, sure he would not say so;
Yet I have comfort if by any means
I get a blessing from my father's hands:
How cheap are good prayers? A poor penny buys
that, by which man up in a minute flies,
And mounts to heaven.
O me, mine uncle sees me!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Now sir, what make you here so near the prison?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I was going, sir, to buy meat for a poor bird I have,
That sits so sadly in the cage of late,
I think he'll die for sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: So sir, your pity will not quit you pains, I fear me;
I shall find that bird I think to be that churlish
Wretch, your father, that now has taken
Shelter here in Ludgate; go too, sir, urge me
Not, you'd best; I have given you warning:
Fawn not on him nor come not near him,
If you'll have my love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: 'Las sir, that lamb
Were most unnatural that should hate the dam.

sp.speaker: Ste,
sp.l: Lamb me no lambs, sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good uncle; alas you know when you lay here.
I succoured you, so let me now help him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yes, as he did me,
To laugh and triumph at my misery;
You freed me with his gold, but 'gainst his will:
For him I might have rotted, and lain still;
So shall he now.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alack the day!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: If him thou pity, 'tis thine own decay:

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread, some charitable man remember
The poor prisoners; bread for the tender mercy,
One penny.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O listen uncle; that's my poor father's voice.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: There let him howl; get you gone, and come not near him

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my soul! what tortures dost thou feel?
Earth ne'er shall find, a son so true,
Yet forced to be unkind.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways, thou pattern of true virtue;
My heart is full, I could even weep, and much ado I had to forbear,
to hear a brother begging in a jail,
That but e'er while spread up a lofty sail
As proudly as the best: o, 'twere a sin
Unpardonable in me, should I not succour him?
Yes, I will do't, yet closely it shall be done,
And he not know from whence his comforts come.
What ho, keeper there, a word I pray.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: What's your pleasure, sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: What's he that at the grate there begged even now.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: One master foster, sir, a decayed citizen new
Come in. Cry you mercy sir, you know him
Better than myself, I think.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I should do, knew he me as I would know
Him: prithee take him from the grate,
And that no more he stand to beg,
There's ten pound to pay his score, and
Take off all his wants; if he demand
Who sends it, tell him, 'tis thine own free
Hand to lend him money.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Well sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Spend what he will, my purse shall pay it all;
And at his parting hence, the poorest prisoner,
And all free citizens that live in Ludgate,
Shall bless his coming in; I'll for his sake
Do something now, that whilst this city stands,
Shall keep the Foster's name engraven so high,
As no black storm shall cloud their memory.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Heaven bless your purpose, sir.

div.stage: Enter Stephens wife, and her sister old Foster's wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sister, there's no way to make sorrow light
But in the noble bearing; be content;
Blows given from heaven are our due punishment;
All ship wracks are no drownings, you see buildings
Made fairer from their ruins; he that I married,
The brother to your husband, lay, you know,
on the same bed of misery, yet now
He's ranked with the best citizens.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O you were born to wealth and
Happiness; ay, to want and scorn!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Come, I will work my husband; stay this grief.
The longest sorrow finds at last relief.
Now sir, your business.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Marry mistress here are two creatures
Scarce able to make one man, desires to speak
With you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What are they, know their names.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay, I know that already; the one is a
Thing that was placed into the
World, by the head and shoulders to be
Wondered at, and 'tis called a knight; the other
Is a coach-horse of the same overriden race;
And that's a foolish gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O, they are my old debtors, Speedwell and Lambskin
Go call them in, and my gentle sister
Comfort yourself and my imprisoned brother,
To whom commend me give to him this gold,
What good I can, I'll do for him be bold.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: May heavenly blessings guard you from all ill:
Never was woman vexed as I am still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now good sir Godfrey and master innocent.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I put my innocent case into your hands
Mistress, as a simple country client thrusts his money
Into a lawyer's, who stands upon no great
Terms to take it.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: We come about the old business, the sickness of the purse lady

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And they'd be loath to keep their beds ith' counter
Mistress; they are afraid of sergeants, master Lambskin,
Knows that mace is a binder.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: No truly it makes me lose for I never smell it, though
it be two streets off, but it gives me a stool presently,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ay, you have been a loose liver always,
'Tis time to look to you.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Fair lady, we are your debtors, and owe you money.
Experience tells us that our bonds are forfeit,
For which your husband threatened to arrest us; my
Shoulders love no such clappings, I love
Tobacco, but would be loath to drink in Woodstreet.
Pipes; some money we will pay ere we go hence:
I speak you see with grave experience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I know it well, sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Had not your husband (When we went about fowling
For the alderman's daughter) driven away the bird
We might have bidden you to a better breakfast;
But now you must take what we can set before you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I am content to do so: you shall find
Nor me nor my husband carry a griping mind.
Now coz, where's your uncle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He's hard at hand, I saw him coming
With the lord maior and aldermen.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Zounds knight, if the mayor come
The shoulder clappers are not far off.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O fear not, I'll be your surety sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Do you not smell poultry ware, sir Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Most horribly, I'll not endure the scent on't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Upon my trust none here shall do you wrong;
What is his business with the alderman?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: About the entertainment of the King
That means to visit London.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Saw you your sad father?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I did; would I might never see man more
Since he so hates my sight; the prison door,
Which gapes for comers in, that mouth of hell,
Shut me out with a churlish cold farewell;
After my fathers most unnatural part
Was played on miseries stage, mine uncle comes
in thunder on me, threatening with black storms
To nail me to the earth, if I relieved my
Poor old father.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Here's my master now gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O gentlemen, you're both welcome,
Have you paid this money on your bonds yet?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not yet sir, but here they come like honest gentlemen
To take some order for it: good sweetheart
Shall it be put to me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Do as you please;
In all thy deeds thou'rt governed with good stars,
Therefore if thou criest peace, I'll not raise wars.
E'en order it how thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thank ye sir; then tell me gentlemen,
What present money can you pay?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Two hundred pound we can lay down.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: And take up seven times as much if we knew
Where to get it; but there's our lamentable ease:
Mistress, if you strip us any nearer, you'll strip the
Skin and all I'll assure you,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: We'll shear no sheep so close.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: No sheep forsooth, but a poor innocent lambskin.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You should be a calf by your white face.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: All your two thousand pound gentlemen we quit,
For your two hundred: go pay the money to
My coz, and receive your two bonds cancelled:
Say sir, are ye content.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Wife I must stand to the arbitrement.
Go cousin, receive their
Money, and sirrah make them drink.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll make them drink if they will; come
Gallants empty your bags, and I'll bombast
Your bellies; this lean gentleman looks
As if he had no lining in's guts, I could
Take him by the leg and hurl him into
The dog-house.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How now sweet wife, what art thou
Musing on?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I must come a-wooing to you sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: A wooing sweet, for what?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: For your brother; o 'tis unmeet
For souls framed by one square to grow uneven,
'Tis like a war amongst the great lights of heaven,
One cannot lose his beauty, but the other
Suffers eclipse; so brother against brother.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Wouldst have me kiss him that would kill me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would you kill a man lying at your feet:
Do good for ill.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thy songs are angels tunes, and on thy wings
I'll fly with thee to heaven.
Thou speakest as I would have thee;
His debts I have justly weighed, and find them light.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: The easier than ta'en off.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou sayest most right,
But I of purpose keep aloof to try
My kinsman; whom I spied most dolefully
Hovering about the grate, where his father cried
With piteous voice, for bread; yet did I chide
And railed against the boy; but my heart says
( howe'er my tongue) it was drowned in tears,
To see such goodness in a son.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Such wheels in children's bosom seldom run.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll lay a wager wife, that this two hundred pound
Paid by these foolish fellows, will by the boy
Be given his father.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Troth would it might:

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: In doing me such wrong he does me right
Ludgate was once my dwelling, and to show
That I true feeling of his misery knew;
Albeit long since blown o'er; so thou'lt consent,
Within that place I'll raise some monument,
Shall keep our names alive till doomsday.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I gladly shall agree.
To any act that tends to charity.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come, where's Mr. Foster? O you lose time sir,
Not meeting fortune that comes to kiss you.
The lord maior and aldermen stay at the Guildhall,
Expecting you, as well to set down order
Touching the entertainment of the King,
As to elect you for the following year a sheriff of London.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Their loves outstrip my merit.
Yet since they lay that load on me, I'll bear it,
And wait in scarlet on my liege and King.
But pray resolve me, master alderman,
Why makes the King this visitation?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Troth sir, to honour me, I thank his highness,
Who with my lord the Cardinal comes along
To see the dedication of my house,
Built for the weary travellers to rest in;
Where stands three hundred beds for their relief,
With meat, drink, and some money when they part,
Which I'll give freely with a willing heart.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: A pious, worthy, and religious act:
Come sir, toth' Guildhall; wife, look to your
Kinsman, watch him near; but do not hinder
He if he relieve his father: come master alderman,
With such sweet incense up your offerings fly,
I'll build one altar more to charity.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter old Foster, his wife, and keeper.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Come, come, be merry sir; do as mourners do at
Funerals, wear your hat in your eyes, and
laugh in your heart.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I have no such fat legacy left me,
To teach me how to play the hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: No? Why look ye sir, you shall want neither
Meat, drink, money, nor any thing that the
House affords, or if any thing abroad like ye,
Sir, here's money, send for what you will sir:
Nay, you shall beg no more at the grate neither.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ha? Is not this Ludgate?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: A jail, a prison, a tomb of men locked up;
Alive and buried?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: 'Tis what you please to call it.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O, at what crevice then hath comfort
Like a sunbeam crept? for all the doors
And windows are of iron, and barred to keep
Her out; I had a limb cut from my body
Dear to me as life; I had a son and brother too;
O grief, they both would give me poison first
In gold, before their hollow palms ten
Drops should hold of nature's drink, cold water,
But to save my life one minute; whence
Should pity come, when my best friends do.
Beat it from this room.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: No matter sir, since you have good meat set
Before you, never ask who sent it; if heaven
Provide for you, and make the fowls of the
Air your. Cators, feed you fat, and be thankful,
And so I leave you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: The keeper is your friend, and powers true balm
Into your smarting wounds; therefore dear
Husband endure the dressing with patience.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O wife, my losses are as numberless as the
Sea's sands that swallowed them. And shall
I in reckoning them, my sad griefs multiply?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: You may sir, but your dim eyes so thick with tears do run.
sp.l: You cannot see from whence your comforts come,
Besides your debts being truly counted cannot
Be great.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: But all my wealth and state lies in the sea's bottom.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: It again may rise.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O never.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Good sir, so hope, for I from heaven espy
An arm to pluck you from this misery.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Sir, there's one without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Go send him in; none comes to do me good
My wealth is lost, now let them take my blood.
Ha? what art thou? Call for the keeper there
And thrust him out of doors, or lock me up.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O 'tis your son, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost
sp.l: I know him not:
I am no King, unless of scorn and woe,
Why kneelest thou then; why dost thou mock me so?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my dear father, hither am I come
Not like a threatening storm to increase your wrack
For I would take all sorrows from your back
To lay them all on my own.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Rise mischief, rise, away and get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O if I be thus hateful to your eye
I will depart, and wish I soon may die;
Yet let your blessing, sir, but fall on me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: My heart still hates thee.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Sweet husband.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Get you both gone;
That misery takes some rest that dwells alone;
Away thou villain.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Heaven can tell, ache but your finger, I to make it
Well, would cut my hand off.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hang thee, hang thee.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Destruction meet thee, turn the key there ho.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good sir: I'm gone, I will not stay to grieve you:
O knew you (For your woes) what pains I feel,
You would not scorn me so. See sir, to cool
Your heat of burning sorrow I have got
Two hundred pounds and glad it is my lot
To lay it down, with reverence at your feet;
No comfort in the world to me is sweet,
Whilst thus you live in moan.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good troth sir, I'll have none on't back,
Could but one penny of it save my life.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Yet stay and hear him; o unnatural strife,
In a hard father's bosom.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I see mine error now: o can there grow
A rose upon a bramble? did there e'er flow
Poison and health together in one tide?
I'm born a man; reason may step aside.
And lead a father's love out of the way:
Forgive me, my good boy, I went astray;
Look, on my knees I beg it; not for joy
Thou bringst this golden rubbish, which I spurn
But glad in this, the heaven's mine eye balls turn,
And fix them right to look upon that face
Where love remains with pity, duty, grace.
O my dear wronged boy!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Gladness o'erwhelms my heart with joy I cannot speak

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Crosses of this foolish world.
Did never grieve my heart with torments more
Than it is now grown light,
With joy and comfort of this happy sight.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Yet wife, I disinherited this boy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your blessings all I crave.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And that enjoy for ever, evermore; my
Blessings fly, to pay thy virtues, love and charity.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Here comes your brother's wife,
welcome dear sister.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thank you; how fare you brother?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Better than your husband's hate could wish me,
That laughs to see my back with sorrow's bow:
But I am rid of half my ague now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Had you an ague then?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Yes, and my heart had every hour a fit.
But now 'thas left me well, and I left it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O, 'tis well cousin, what make you hear I pray?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: To support a weak house falling to decay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis well, if you can do't, and that the timber
You underprop it with be all your own.
Hark coz, where's your uncle's money?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Faith aunt 'tis gone, but not at dice,
Nor drabbing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, I believe with your uncle's gold your father
You relieve.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You are saved believing so, your belief's true.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You cut large thongs of that's another's due
And you will answer't ill: now in good troth
I laugh at this jest, much good do them both:
My wager I had won, had I but laid.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What has my poor boy done, that you have
Made so much blood rise in's cheeks?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Nothing dear brother, indeed all's well:
The course that he has run I like and love,
Let him hold on the same;
A sons love to a father none can blame;
I will not leave your brother's ●on heart
Till I have beaten it soft with my entreats.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: 'Twill ne'er be music 'tis so full of frets.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Frets make best music: strings the higher
Racked sound sweetest.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And sound nothing when they are cracked,
As is his love to me, and mine to him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I hope you both in smoother streams shall swim:
He's now the sheriff of London, and in counsel
set at the Guildhall, in his scarlet gown
With mayor and aldermen, how to receive the King,
Who comes to see master Bruin's hospital
To morrow consecrated by'th Cardinal,
And old saint Marie's spittle, here by Shoreditch.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I sister, he and you may sit about what you will;
Heaven I'm sure prospers it, but I am ever crossed;
You have been bound for thee great voyages,
Yet never run a ground; maid, wife, and widow,
And wife again; have spread full and fair sails,
No wracks you e'er did dread, nor e'er felt any;
But even close ashore, I'm sunk, and midst of
All my wealth made poor.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You must thank heaven.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I do indeed, for all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sister, that hand can raise that gives the fall.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Master foster, the new sheriff your brother
Is come to Ludgate, and I am come in haste
To know your pleasure, if you would see him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I'll see a fury first, hence, clap to the door I prithee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why, 'tis your brother sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Father let's fly the thunder of his rage.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Stand valiantly, and let me bear the storm, all hurts
That are, and ruins in your bosoms I'll repair.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Where's the keeper, go sir, take
My officers, and see your prisoners
Presently conveyed from Ludgate unto
Newgate, and the counters.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Let the constables of the wards assist you,
Go, dispatch and take these with you; how now,
What mak'st thou here thou caitiff? had comest
Thou to stitch his wounds that seeks to cut
My throat, dar'st thou in despite relieve this
Dotard?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Get thee from my sight, thou devil in red;
Com'st thou in scarlet pride to tread on thy poor
Brother in a jail, is there but one small conduit -
Pipe that runs could water to my comfort, and
Wouldst thou cut off that thou cruel man?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yes, I'll stop that pipe that thou mayst pining sit,
When drops but fell on me, thou poisoned'st it:
Thou thrust'st a son's name from thy cruel breast,
For clothing of his uncle; now that uncle
Shall thrust him naked forth for clothing thee,
Banished for ever from my wealth and me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Thou canst not be to nature so uneven,
To punish that which has a pay from heaven;
Pirty I mean, and duty; wouldst thou strike?
Wound me then, that will kill thee if I can,
Thou'rt no brother, and I'll be no man.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou ravest.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: How can I choose? thou makest me mad,
For shame thou shouldst not make these white hairs sad;
Churl, beat not my poor boy, let him not lose
Thy love for my sake, I had rather bruise
My soul with torments for a thousand years, could
I but live them, rather than salt tears thy
Malice draw from him; see here's thy gold,
Tell it, none's stole, my woes can ne'er be told.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O misery is nature quite forgotten?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Choke with thy dunghill muck, and vex me not.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No, keep it, he perhaps, that money stole
From me, to give it thee, for which to vex thy
Soul, I turn him forth of doors, make him
Thy heir, of jails, miseries, curses, and despair;
For here I disinherit him of all.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: No matter, lands to him in heaven will fall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 husband.

sp.speaker: M. 〈◊〉.
sp.l: ●other.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Dear uncle.
And 〈◊〉, the devils thumbs stop thine ears.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'll make thee wash those curses off with tears.
Keeper, away with him out of my sight,
And do sir, as I charged you.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Yes sir; I will.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Poor tyranny; when lions weak lambs kill.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How now wife, art vexed yet?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Never so well content, believe me sir;
Your mildness wears this mask of cruelty well.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'm glad they're gone, mine eyes with rain did swell,
And much ado they had from pouring down:
The keeper knows my mind, wife I have paid
My brother's debts; and when he's out of door:
To march to Newgate, he shall be set free.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O let me kiss thee for this charity;
But for your cousin sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: He's my lives best health,
The boy shall not miscarry for more wealth
Than London gates look safe up every night,
My breath in black clouds flies, my thoughts
Are white.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why from Ludgate do you remove prisoners?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: This is my meaning wife;
I'll take the prison down and build it new,
With leads to walk on, rooms large and fair:
For when myself lay there, the noisome air,
Choked up my spirits, and none better know,
What prisoners feel, than they that taste the woe.
The workmen are appointed for the business,
I will have't dispatched before 'tis thought on.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: In good deeds I will walk hand in hand with you,
There is a fair tenement, adjoining close to the gate
That was my fathers, I'll give it freely, take it down,
And add so much ground to the work.
'Tis fairly given.
Thy soul on prisoners prayers shall mount to heaven:
The plumbers and the workmen have surveyed the ground
From Paddington; from whence I'll have laid pipes
long to London to convey sweet water into Ludgate;
From fresh springs: when charity tunes thee, pipe the
Poor man sings.
How now keeper.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: The prisoners are removed sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: What did you with my brother?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: As you commanded sir, I have discharged him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How did he meet that unexpected kindness?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Troth sir, as a man overcome 'twixt grief and gladness,
But turning to his son, he fetched a sigh
So violent, as if his heart would break,
And silent, wept, having no power to speak.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas good old man, some sweet bird must sing,
And give his sorrows present comforting.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Not yet, I'll wrack his sorrows to the height,
And of themselves they'll then sink softly down;
Keeper, go thou again after my brother,
Charge in my name him and his son to appear
Before the King, to whom I will make known
Their wrongs against me; showing just cause
To disinherit both by course of law. Be gone.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What's your meaning sir?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou shall know that anon.
The heavens oft scowl, clouds thicken, winds blow high,
Yet the brightest sun clears all, and so will I.

div.stage: Enter, Henry the third Mountford, Pembroke, Arundell, lord Maior, sheriff Foster, Cardinal, bruine, etc.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O! welcome is all love, our people's shouts
In their heart's language, make our ben-venues,
Most high and sovereign; we return all thanks
Unto our loving citizens, chiefly to you sir,
Whose pious work invites our majesty to royalize
This place with our best presence, accompanied with this
Reverend Cardinal; would we might, after many broils,
End our days in these religious toils;
we would work most faithfully; but bounteous sir,
How do you call your buildings?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Unless it please your majesty to change it,
I call it, domus dei.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The house of God, it is too good to change, pray you proceed.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: These are my ends to all distressed Christians,
Whose travails this way bends the hospital,
Shall free succour be, for three days, and three nights
Sojourn, for diet, and lodging, both sweet, and
Satisfying; and if their need be such, as much in
Coin, as shall for three days more defray their
Further travail; this unto heaven, be you
Testator, good my liege, and witness with me, noble
Gentlemen, most free and faithfully, I dedicate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An honourable work, and deserves large memory.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: 'Tis a good example, 'tis pity 'tis no better followed.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.p: But say sir, now in some future age, perhaps some two or three hundred year behind us, this place
sp.l: Intended for a use so charitable, should be
Unhallowed again, by villainous inhabitants; say whores,
In the stead of Christians, and your hospitable
Tenements, turned into stews; would not this grieve
You in your grave?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: If my grave were capable of grief: sure it would sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prithee be a false prophet.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: I will, if I can, my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let now our heralds in the streets proclaim,
The title, and office, of this hospital;
Make known to all distressed travellers, that
We'll accept this charitable house, this domus dei:
Shall be their free sojourn, as is proposed.

div.stage: Enter the one way, Stephens wife, the other, mistress Foster, Jane, old Foster, Robert and keeper, all kneel.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What are these petitioners?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Each hath a knee for duty, the other for petition,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rise, your duty's done, your petitions shall need
No knees, so your intents be honest, does
None here know them?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yes my good lord, there's now a wonder in your sight.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A wonder, master sheriff, you mean for beauty.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No my liege, I would not so boast mine
Own wife, but 'tis a wonder that excels beauty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A wonder in a woman; what is't I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Patience my liege, this is a woman that
Was never vexed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You may boast it largely; 'tis a subject's happiness
Above a Queen's; have you suits to us?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am the suppliant plaintiff, royal Henry
From me their griefs take their original.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Even what your grace shall please to make of me;
I was the son to this distressed father, until he
Took his paternity off, and threw me from his love,
Than I became son to mine uncle by adoption,
Who likewise that hath ta'en away again,
And thrown me back to poverty; never was
Son so tossed betwixt two fathers, yet knows
Not one, for still the richest does despise his heir,
And I am back expulsed into despair.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This may your vices cause.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: For that I come to your impartial censure for a doom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We hear, speak on, we know the parties,
Each one relate his grief, and if it lie in us,
We'll yield relief; 'tis first requisite that we
Know of you sir, the cause of this your son's disinheritance

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Before I understood his virtuous mind,
Or weighed his disposition to be kind,
I did that froward work; this now great man,
Was an unthrifty wretch, a prodigal then.
And I disdained to know his brotherhood,
Denied relief to him; this child kind and good
Against my contradiction, did him relieve, as his
distressed uncle, at this I chide; for bade,
Still he holds on his course,
He grows more kind, and he in wasting worse;
My rage continued as it had begun,
And in that rage I threw away my son.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: The like plead I, my lord: for when my state
Had raised itself by an uncertain fate,
I took this outcast child, made him my own,
As full and free, as I myself had swoon
The seed that brought him forth; for this my love,
His obliged duty presently did prove
A traitor to my trust, against my will,
Succouring that foe, which I did love so ill,
Only for hating him; my charity being thus
Abused, and quit with injury, what could I then
But as his father erst, so I again might throw
Him from my love? for worse is love abused
Then new born hate, and should be so refused:
I did a father's part, if it were bad,
Blame him for both, there I my pattern had.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You fall betwixt two pillars sir, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Unhappy fate, my lord, yet thus I plead:
For this my father's hate I might deserve,
I broke his precepts, and did unchildly swerve
From his commission, I to my uncle gave
What was my fathers, striving thereby to save
His fall'n repute; he raged, I did it still,
Yet must confess as it was well, 'twas ill,
Well in my love, methought , ill to my fate:
For I thereby ruined my own estate,
But that mine uncle throws me forth of door
For the same cause he took me in before,
Beats forest, 'gainst my bosom; if 'twere good
To take from a father for an uncle's food,
In laws of love and nature, how much rather
Might I abridge an uncle for a father?
Charity's, a virtue generally stands,
and should dispersed be through all men's hands.
Then would you keep't alone; for when your heir
I first adopted was, charity was there:
How errs your judgement then? seeing you see
What was good in you, makes sin in me;
You'll say my father did it, o throw away
That soul excuse; let not discretion stray
So far aside ; if custom lawful make,
Than sin were lawful for example's sake;
Nor were these wasted goods only your own,
Since part was mine having adoption;
Then do him right, my lord, yet do no wrong,
For where my duty failed my love was strong.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: With an impartial ear we have heard your
Loving story, 'tis both fair and honest.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O let me now anticipate your grace,
And casting off the shadow of a face,
Show my hearts true figure, how have I strived
To make this forced counterfeit long lived,
And now it bursts; come into my heart,
I have two jewels here shall never part
From my love's eye watch, two worthy to be filled,
On times best record; a woman and a child,
Now sir, to you I come, we must be friends,
Though envy wills not so, yet love contends
'Gainst envy and her forces; my young years
Say I must offer first, a peace in tears.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O let my shame my bosom's centre break!
Love is to young it coys, but cannot speak.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You bless mine eyes with objects that become
The theater of Kings to look upon.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: The keeper is discharged sir, your debts are paid,
And from the prison you're a new free man made:
There's not a creditor can ask you ought,
As your son did form, so have I bought
Your liberty with mine, and to increase it more,
Because I know bare liberty is poor
without assistance: to raise your state again,
The thirds of mine are yours, say you amen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, not to that, you are kind brothers now,
Divide by halves that love, and I'll allow.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou art only wise in virtue, as thou setst down,
So let it be, half my estate's your own.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: It whole redounds again, for I am yours;
Forget this minute my forgetful hours.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O, they are buried all sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This union's good, such league should ever be in brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yet without boast, my liege, let me relate
One small thing more, remorse of my own state,
And my dear brother's worse succession;
For that we both have prisoners been in one
Selfsame place of woe, and felt those throws
That Ludgate yields; my charity bestows
Some alms of comfort: keeper you can speak it.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: And many hundreds more sir, you have re-edified
And built it fair, adding more ground to it,
And by pipes of lead from Paddington, drawn
Water thither, free for all prisoners, lodgings
Likewise free, and a hundred pounds yearly, to make
Them fues for better comfort: all this is almost finished:

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A worthy work, the better being done in the founders ere,
Not left unto succession.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O my good lord, I ever keep in mind an English
Sentence, which my tutor is, and teaches me to act my
Charity with mine own hands so ●full is
Performance, when the benefactor's dead.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What is't I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: This my good lord, women are forgetful.
Children unkind, executors covetous, and take what they find,
If any man ask where the deads' goods became,
The executor swears he died a poor man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have prevented well, so has this good alderman,
I wish you many scholars.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You make some doubt of me in this sir;
did you not say that women were forgetful,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have vexed her now sir, how do you answer that?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No my lord, she's exempt from the proverb.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No my lord, I'll help it better, I do confess
That women are forgetful, yet ne'er the less
I am exempt, I know my fate, and find
My dear husband must not leave me behind,
But I must go before him, and 'tis said,
The grave's good rest when women go first to bed.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thanks for thy excuse good wife, but not thy love
To fill my grave before me, I would not live to see that day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Prithee no more, I had rather be angry than flattered.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have a wonder master sheriff, a priceless jewel.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Many jewels my good lord; a brother, wife, and child,
For this I would have strove even with a father,
Howe'er rough storms did in my brows appear,
Within my bosom it was always clear.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I give him to you now sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I take him, and to him back do give,
All that myself behind in state shall leave.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And all that you gave me, I do bestow,
So in one hour become full heir to two.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I claim a third by this bonds virtue,
See as a third father, thou art heir to those.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I will not go to him father on any of these conditions.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You shall have love to boot too, sweet Jane.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Nay, and you play booty, I dare not trust you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What shall I say, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉,
Tied in a true-love's knot, ne'er to part.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I marry sir, these are better conditions than the
Inheritance of three fathers; let me have
Love in esse, let lands follow in posse:
Now I'll have thee as fast as the priest
Can dispatch us, let him read as fast as he can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The liveliest harmony that ere I heard;
All instruments compared to these sweet tunes,
Are dull and harsh; I joy to see so good a child.
A woman wonder, brothers reconciled;
You worthy sir, did invite us to a feast,
We'll not forget it, but will be your guest,
Because we'll view these wonders o'er again,
Whose records do deserve a brazen pen,
But this above the rest, in golden text,
Shall be insculpt; a woman never vexed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
